\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{sample_n}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ungroup}\NormalTok{()}

\NormalTok{cors <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{galton_heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{gather}\NormalTok{(parent, parentHeight, father}\OperatorTok{:}\NormalTok{mother) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{child =} \KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(gender }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "female"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"daughter"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"son"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{unite}\NormalTok{(pair, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"parent"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"child"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(pair) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{cor =} \KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(parentHeight, childHeight))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Are these differences statistically significant? To answer this, we will compute the slopes of the regression line along with their standard errors. Start by using \texttt{lm} and the \textbf{broom} package to compute the slopes LSE and the standard errors.

2. Repeat the exercise above, but compute a confidence interval as well.

3. Plot the confidence intervals and notice that they overlap, which implies that the data is consistent with the inheritance of height being independent of sex.

4. Because we are selecting children at random, we can actually do something like a permutation test here. Repeat the computation of correlations 100 times taking a different sample each time. Hint: use similar code to what we used with simulations.

5. Fit a linear regression model to obtain the effects of BB and HR on Runs (at the team level) in 1971. Use the \texttt{tidy} function in the \textbf{broom} package to obtain the results in a data frame.

6. Now let's repeat the above for each year since 1961 and make a plot. Use \texttt{do} and the \textbf{broom} package to fit this model for every year since 1961.

7. Use the results of the previous exercise to plot the estimated effects of BB on runs.

8. \textbf{Advanced}. Write a function that takes R, HR, and BB as arguments and fits two linear models: \texttt{R\ \textasciitilde{}\ BB} and \texttt{R\textasciitilde{}BB+HR}. Then use the \texttt{do} function to obtain the \texttt{BB} for both models for each year since 1961. Then plot these against each other as a function of time.

\hypertarget{case-study-moneyball-continued}{%
\section{Case study: Moneyball (continued)}\label{case-study-moneyball-continued}}

In trying to answer how well BBs predict runs, data exploration led us to a model:

\[
\mbox{E}[R \mid BB = x_1, HR = x_2] = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2
\]

Here, the data is approximately normal and conditional distributions were also normal. Thus, we are justified in using a linear model:

\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_{i,1} + \beta_2 x_{i,2} + \varepsilon_i
\]

with \(Y_i\) runs per game for team \(i\), \(x_{i,1}\) walks per game, and \(x_{i,2}\). To use \texttt{lm} here, we need to let the function know we have two predictor variables. So we use the \texttt{+} symbol as follows:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Teams }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{%in%}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1961}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{2001}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{BB =}\NormalTok{ BB}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G, }\DataTypeTok{HR =}\NormalTok{ HR}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G,  }\DataTypeTok{R =}\NormalTok{ R}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(R }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{BB }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{HR, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ .)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can use \texttt{tidy} to see a nice summary:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{(fit, }\DataTypeTok{conf.int =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{) }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When we fit the model with only one variable, the estimated slopes were 0.735328761775897 and 1.84482406982372 for BB and HR, respectively. Note that when fitting the multivariate model both go down, with the BB effect decreasing much more.

Now we want to construct a metric to pick players, we need to consider singles, doubles, and triples as well. Can we build a model that predicts runs based on all these outcomes?

We now are going to take somewhat of a ``leap of faith'' and assume that these five variables are jointly normal. This means that if we pick any one of them, and hold the other four fixed, the relationship with the outcome is linear and the slope does not depend on the four values held constant. If this is true, then a linear model for our data is:

\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_{i,1} + \beta_2 x_{i,2} + \beta_3 x_{i,3}+ \beta_4 x_{i,4} + \beta_5 x_{i,5} + \varepsilon_i
\]

with \(x_{i,1}, x_{i,2}, x_{i,3}, x_{i,4}, x_{i,5}\) representing BB, singles, doubles, triples, and HR respectively.

Using \texttt{lm}, we can quickly find the LSE for the parameters using:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Teams }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{%in%}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1961}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{2001}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{BB =}\NormalTok{ BB }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{singles =}\NormalTok{ (H }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{X2B }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{X3B }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{HR) }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{doubles =}\NormalTok{ X2B }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{triples =}\NormalTok{ X3B }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{HR =}\NormalTok{ HR }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{G,}
         \DataTypeTok{R =}\NormalTok{ R }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{G) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(R }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{BB }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{singles }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{doubles }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{triples }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{HR, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ .)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can see the coefficients using \texttt{tidy}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{coefs <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{(fit, }\DataTypeTok{conf.int =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{coefs}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To see how well our metric actually predicts runs, we can predict the number of runs for each team in 2002 using the function \texttt{predict}, then make a plot:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{Teams }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{%in%}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{2002}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{BB =}\NormalTok{ BB}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{singles =}\NormalTok{ (H}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{X2B}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{X3B}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{HR)}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{doubles =}\NormalTok{ X2B}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{triples =}\NormalTok{X3B}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G, }
         \DataTypeTok{HR=}\NormalTok{HR}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G,}
         \DataTypeTok{R=}\NormalTok{R}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G)  }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{R_hat =} \KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ .)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(R_hat, R, }\DataTypeTok{label =}\NormalTok{ teamID)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_text}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{nudge_x=}\FloatTok{0.1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{cex =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_abline}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/model-predicts-runs-1} \end{center}

Our model does quite a good job as demonstrated by the fact that points from the observed versus predicted plot fall close to the identity line.

So instead of using batting average, or just number of HR, as a measure of picking players, we can use our fitted model to form a metric that relates more directly to run production. Specifically, to define a metric for player A, we imagine a team made up of players just like player A and use our fitted regression model to predict how many runs this team would produce. The formula would look like this:
-2.769 +
0.371 \(\times\) BB +
0.519 \(\times\) singles +
0.771 \(\times\) doubles +
1.24 \(\times\) triples +
1.443 \(\times\) HR.

To define a player-specific metric, we have a bit more work to do. A challenge here is that we derived the metric for teams, based on team-level summary statistics. For example, the HR value that is entered into the equation is HR per game for the entire team. If we compute the HR per game for a player, it will be much lower since the total is accumulated by 9 batters. Furthermore, if a player only plays part of the game and gets fewer opportunities than average, it is still considered a game played. For players, a rate that takes into account opportunities is the per-plate-appearance rate.

To make the per-game team rate comparable to the per-plate-appearance player rate, we compute the average number of team plate appearances per game:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pa_per_game <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Batting }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{2002}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(teamID) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{pa_per_game =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(AB}\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{BB)}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(G)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{pull}\NormalTok{(pa_per_game) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\NormalTok{mean}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We compute the per-plate-appearance rates for players available in 2002 on data from 1997-2001. To avoid small sample artifacts, we filter players with less than 200 plate appearances per year. Here is the entire calculation in one line:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{players <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Batting }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{%in%}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1997}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{2001}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(playerID) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{PA =}\NormalTok{ BB }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{AB) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{G =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(PA)}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{pa_per_game,}
    \DataTypeTok{BB =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(BB)}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G,}
    \DataTypeTok{singles =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(H}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{X2B}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{X3B}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{HR)}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G,}
    \DataTypeTok{doubles =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(X2B)}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G, }
    \DataTypeTok{triples =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(X3B)}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G, }
    \DataTypeTok{HR =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(HR)}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{G,}
    \DataTypeTok{AVG =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(H)}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(AB),}
    \DataTypeTok{PA =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(PA)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(PA }\OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1000}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{G) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{R_hat =} \KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ .))}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The player-specific predicted runs computed here can be interpreted as the number of runs we predict a team will score if all batters are exactly like that player. The distribution shows that there is wide variability across players:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(R_hat, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ players, }\DataTypeTok{binwidth =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \KeywordTok{I}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/r-hat-hist-1} \end{center}

\hypertarget{adding-salary-and-position-information}{%
\subsection{Adding salary and position information}\label{adding-salary-and-position-information}}

To actually build the team, we will need to know their salaries as well as their defensive position. For this, we join the \texttt{players} data frame we just created with the player information data frame included in some of the other Lahman data tables. We will learn more about the join function we learned in Section \ref{joins}.

Start by adding the 2002 salary of each player:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{players <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Salaries }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{2002}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(playerID, salary) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{right_join}\NormalTok{(players, }\DataTypeTok{by=}\StringTok{"playerID"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Next, we add their defensive position. This is a somewhat complicated task because players play more than one position each year. The \textbf{Lahman} package table \texttt{Appearances} tells how many games each player played in each position, so we can pick the position that was most played using \texttt{which.max} on each row. We use \texttt{apply} to do this. However, because some players are traded, they appear more than once on the table, so we first sum their appearances across teams.
Here, we pick the one position the player most played using the \texttt{top\_n} function. To make sure we only pick one position, in the case of ties, we pick the first row of the resulting data frame. We also remove the \texttt{OF} position which stands for outfielder, a generalization of three positions: left field (LF), center field (CF), and right field (RF). We also remove pitchers since they don't bat in the league in which the A's play.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{position_names <-}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{paste0}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"G_"}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"p"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"c"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"1b"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"2b"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"3b"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"ss"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"lf"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"cf"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"rf"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"dh"}\NormalTok{))}

\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Appearances }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{2002}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(playerID) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize_at}\NormalTok{(position_names, sum) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ungroup}\NormalTok{()}
  
\NormalTok{pos <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(position_names) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{apply}\NormalTok{(., }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, which.max) }
\CommentTok{#> Note: Using an external vector in selections is ambiguous.}
\CommentTok{#> i Use `all_of(position_names)` instead of `position_names` to silence this message.}
\CommentTok{#> i See <https://tidyselect.r-lib.org/reference/faq-external-vector.html>.}
\CommentTok{#> This message is displayed once per session.}

\NormalTok{players <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{tibble}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{playerID =}\NormalTok{ tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{playerID, }\DataTypeTok{POS =}\NormalTok{ position_names[pos]) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{POS =} \KeywordTok{str_to_upper}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{str_remove}\NormalTok{(POS, }\StringTok{"G_"}\NormalTok{))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(POS }\OperatorTok{!=}\StringTok{ "P"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{right_join}\NormalTok{(players, }\DataTypeTok{by=}\StringTok{"playerID"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(POS)  }\OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(salary))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Finally, we add their first and last name:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{players <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Master }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(playerID, nameFirst, nameLast, debut) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{debut =} \KeywordTok{as.Date}\NormalTok{(debut)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{right_join}\NormalTok{(players, }\DataTypeTok{by=}\StringTok{"playerID"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If you are a baseball fan, you will recognize the top 10 players:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{players }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(nameFirst, nameLast, POS, salary, R_hat) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{desc}\NormalTok{(R_hat)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{top_n}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{) }
\CommentTok{#> Selecting by R_hat}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{picking-nine-players}{%
\subsection{Picking nine players}\label{picking-nine-players}}

On average, players with a higher metric have higher salaries:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{players }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(salary, R_hat, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ POS)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_x_log10}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/predicted-runs-vs-salary-1} \end{center}

We can search for good deals by looking at players who produce many more runs than others with similar salaries. We can use this table to decide what players to pick and keep our total salary below the 40 million dollars Billy Beane had to work with. This can be done using what computer scientists call linear programming. This is not something we teach, but here are the position players selected with this approach:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(reshape2)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(lpSolve)}

\NormalTok{players <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{players }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(lubridate}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{year}\NormalTok{(debut) }\OperatorTok{<}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1998}\NormalTok{) }
\NormalTok{constraint_matrix <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{acast}\NormalTok{(players, POS }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{playerID, }\DataTypeTok{fun.aggregate =}\NormalTok{ length)}
\NormalTok{npos <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{nrow}\NormalTok{(constraint_matrix)}
\NormalTok{constraint_matrix <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rbind}\NormalTok{(constraint_matrix, }\DataTypeTok{salary =}\NormalTok{ players}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{salary)}
\NormalTok{constraint_dir <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rep}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"=="}\NormalTok{, npos), }\StringTok{"<="}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{constraint_limit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rep}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, npos), }\DecValTok{40}\OperatorTok{*}\DecValTok{10}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{lp_solution <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{lp}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"max"}\NormalTok{, players}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{R_hat,}
\NormalTok{                  constraint_matrix, constraint_dir, constraint_limit,}
                  \DataTypeTok{all.int =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{) }
\NormalTok{our_team <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{players }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(lp_solution}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{solution }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{desc}\NormalTok{(R_hat))}
\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{our_team }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(nameFirst, nameLast, POS, salary, R_hat) }
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{is_html_output}\NormalTok{())\{}
\NormalTok{  knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\StringTok{"html"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\NormalTok{kableExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable_styling}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{bootstrap_options =} \StringTok{"striped"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{full_width =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\} }\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{\{}
\NormalTok{  knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\StringTok{"latex"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{booktabs =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\NormalTok{kableExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable_styling}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{font_size =} \DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-regression-fallacy}{%
\section{The regression fallacy}\label{the-regression-fallacy}}

Wikipedia defines the \emph{sophomore slump} as:

\begin{quote}
A sophomore slump or sophomore jinx or sophomore jitters refers to an instance in which a second, or sophomore, effort fails to live up to the standards of the first effort. It is commonly used to refer to the apathy of students (second year of high school, college or university), the performance of athletes (second season of play), singers/bands (second album), television shows (second seasons) and movies (sequels/prequels).
\end{quote}

In Major League Baseball, the rookie of the year (ROY) award is given to the first-year player who is judged to have performed the best. The \emph{sophmore slump} phrase is used to describe the observation that ROY award winners don't do as well during their second year. For example, this Fox Sports article\footnote{\url{http://www.foxsports.com/mlb/story/kris-bryant-carlos-correa-rookies-of-year-award-matt-duffy-francisco-lindor-kang-sano-120715}} asks ``Will MLB's tremendous rookie class of 2015 suffer a sophomore slump?''.

Does the data confirm the existence of a sophomore slump? Let's take a look. Examining the data for batting average, we see that this observation holds true for the top performing ROYs:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(Lahman)}
\NormalTok{playerInfo <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Fielding }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(playerID) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{desc}\NormalTok{(G)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\NormalTok{ungroup }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{left_join}\NormalTok{(Master, }\DataTypeTok{by=}\StringTok{"playerID"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(playerID, nameFirst, nameLast, POS)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{ROY <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{AwardsPlayers }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(awardID }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Rookie of the Year"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{left_join}\NormalTok{(playerInfo, }\DataTypeTok{by=}\StringTok{"playerID"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{rename}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{rookie_year =}\NormalTok{ yearID) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{right_join}\NormalTok{(Batting, }\DataTypeTok{by=}\StringTok{"playerID"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{AVG =}\NormalTok{ H}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{AB) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(POS }\OperatorTok{!=}\StringTok{ "P"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{ROY <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{ROY }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{rookie_year }\OperatorTok{|}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{yearID }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{rookie_year}\OperatorTok{+}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(playerID) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{rookie =} \KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{min}\NormalTok{(yearID), }\StringTok{"rookie"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"sophomore"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{n}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\NormalTok{ungroup }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(playerID, rookie_year, rookie, nameFirst, nameLast, AVG) }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{ROY <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{ROY }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{spread}\NormalTok{(rookie, AVG) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{desc}\NormalTok{(rookie)) }
\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{ROY }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(nameFirst, nameLast, rookie_year, rookie, sophomore)}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{is_html_output}\NormalTok{())\{}
\NormalTok{  knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\StringTok{"html"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\NormalTok{kableExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable_styling}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{bootstrap_options =} \StringTok{"striped"}\NormalTok{, }
                              \DataTypeTok{full_width =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\} }\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{\{}
\NormalTok{  knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\StringTok{"latex"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{booktabs =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\NormalTok{kableExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable_styling}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{font_size =} \DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In fact, the proportion of players that have a lower batting average their sophomore year is 0.686.

So is it ``jitters'' or ``jinx''? To answer this question, let's turn our attention to all players that played the 2013 and 2014 seasons and batted more than 130 times (minimum to win Rookie of the Year).

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{two_years <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{Batting }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(yearID }\OperatorTok{%in%}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{2013}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{2014}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(playerID, yearID) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(AB) }\OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{130}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{AVG =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(H)}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(AB)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\NormalTok{ungroup }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{spread}\NormalTok{(yearID, AVG) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2013}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2014}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{left_join}\NormalTok{(playerInfo, }\DataTypeTok{by=}\StringTok{"playerID"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(POS}\OperatorTok{!=}\StringTok{"P"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{POS) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{desc}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2013}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(nameFirst, nameLast, }\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2013}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2014}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` regrouping output by 'playerID' (override with `.groups` argument)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\NormalTok{\} }\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{\{}
\NormalTok{  knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\StringTok{"latex"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{booktabs =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\NormalTok{kableExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{kable_styling}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{font_size =} \DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}

Adam & Rosales & 0.190 & 0.262\\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\endgroup{}
\end{table}

Their batting averages mostly go up! Is this some sort of reverse sophomore slump? It is not. There is no such thing as the sophomore slump. This is all explained with a simple statistical fact: the correlation for performance in two separate years is high, but not perfect:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2013}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2014}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ two_years)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.4\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/regression-fallacy-1} \end{center}

The correlation is 0.46 and
the data look very much like a bivariate normal distribution, which means we predict a 2014 batting average \(Y\) for any given player that had a 2013 batting average \(X\) with:

\[ \frac{Y - .255}{.032} = 0.46 \left( \frac{X - .261}{.023}\right) \]

Because the correlation is not perfect, regression tells us that, on average, expect high performers from 2013 to do a bit worse in 2014. It's not a jinx; it's just due to chance. The ROY are selected from the top values of \(X\) so it is expected that \(Y\) will regress to the mean.

\hypertarget{measurement-error-models}{%
\section{Measurement error models}\label{measurement-error-models}}

Up to now, all our linear regression examples have been applied to two or more random variables. We assume the pairs are bivariate normal and use this to motivate a linear model. This approach covers most real-life examples of linear regression. The other major application comes from measurement errors models. In these applications, it is common to have a non-random covariate, such as time, and randomness is introduced from measurement error rather than sampling or natural variability.

To understand these models, imagine you are Galileo in the 16th century trying to describe the velocity of a falling object. An assistant climbs the Tower of Pisa and drops a ball, while several other assistants record the position at different times. Let's simulate some data using the equations we know today and adding some measurement error. The \textbf{dslabs} function \texttt{rfalling\_object} generates these simulations:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\NormalTok{falling_object <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rfalling_object}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The assistants hand the data to Galileo and this is what he sees:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{falling_object }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(time, observed_distance)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ylab}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Distance in meters"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{xlab}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Time in seconds"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/gravity-1} \end{center}

Galileo does not know the exact equation, but by looking at the plot above, he deduces that the position should follow a parabola, which we can write like this:

\[ f(x) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x + \beta_2 x^2\]

The data does not fall exactly on a parabola. Galileo knows this is due to measurement error. His helpers make mistakes when measuring the distance. To account for this, he models the data with:

\[ Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_i + \beta_2 x_i^2 + \varepsilon_i, i=1,\dots,n \]

with \(Y_i\) representing distance in meters, \(x_i\) representing time in seconds, and \(\varepsilon\) accounting for measurement error. The measurement error is assumed to be random, independent from each other, and having the same distribution for each \(i\). We also assume that there is no bias, which means the expected value \(\mbox{E}[\varepsilon] = 0\).

Note that this is a linear model because it is a linear combination of known quantities (\(x\) and \(x^2\) are known) and unknown parameters (the \(\beta\)s are unknown parameters to Galileo). Unlike our previous examples, here \(x\) is a fixed quantity; we are not conditioning.

To pose a new physical theory and start making predictions about other falling objects, Galileo needs actual numbers, rather than unknown parameters. Using LSE seems like a reasonable approach. How do we find the LSE?

LSE calculations do not require the errors to be approximately normal. The \texttt{lm} function will find the \(\beta\) s that will minimize the residual sum of squares:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{falling_object }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{time_sq =}\NormalTok{ time}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(observed_distance}\OperatorTok{~}\NormalTok{time}\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{time_sq, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{.)}
\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{(fit)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Let's check if the estimated parabola fits the data. The \textbf{broom} function \texttt{augment} lets us do this easily:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{augment}\NormalTok{(fit) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(time, observed_distance)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(time, .fitted), }\DataTypeTok{col =} \StringTok{"blue"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/falling-object-fit-1} \end{center}

Thanks to my high school physics teacher, I know that the equation for the trajectory of a falling object is:

\[d = h_0 + v_0 t -  0.5 \times 9.8 t^2\]

with \(h_0\) and \(v_0\) the starting height and velocity, respectively. The data we simulated above followed this equation and added measurement error to simulate \texttt{n} observations for dropping the ball \((v_0=0)\) from the tower of Pisa \((h_0=55.86)\).

These are consistent with the parameter estimates:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{(fit, }\DataTypeTok{conf.int =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The Tower of Pisa height is within the confidence interval for \(\beta_0\), the initial velocity 0 is in the confidence interval for \(\beta_1\) (note the p-value is larger than 0.05), and the acceleration constant is in a confidence interval for \(-2 \times \beta_2\).

\hypertarget{exercises-36}{%
\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-36}}

Since the 1980s, sabermetricians have used a summary statistic different from batting average to evaluate players. They realized walks were important and that doubles, triples, and HRs, should be weighed more than singles. As a result, they proposed the following metric:

\[
\frac{\mbox{BB}}{\mbox{PA}} + \frac{\mbox{Singles} + 2 \mbox{Doubles} + 3 \mbox{Triples} + 4\mbox{HR}}{\mbox{AB}}
\]

They called this on-base-percentage plus slugging percentage (OPS). Although the sabermetricians probably did not use regression, here we show how this metric is close to what one gets with regression.

1. Compute the OPS for each team in the 2001 season. Then plot Runs per game versus OPS.

2. For every year since 1961, compute the correlation between runs per game and OPS; then plot these correlations as a function of year.

3. Note that we can rewrite OPS as a weighted average of BBs, singles, doubles, triples, and HRs. We know that the weights for doubles, triples, and HRs are 2, 3, and 4 times that of singles. But what about BB? What is the weight for BB relative to singles? Hint: the weight for BB relative to singles will be a function of AB and PA.

4. Note that the weight for BB, \(\frac{\mbox{AB}}{\mbox{PA}}\), will change from team to team. To see how variable it is, compute and plot this quantity for each team for each year since 1961. Then plot it again, but instead of computing it for every team, compute and plot the ratio for the entire year. Then, once you are convinced that there is not much of a time or team trend, report the overall average.

5. So now we know that the formula for OPS is proportional to \(0.91 \times \mbox{BB} + \mbox{singles} + 2 \times \mbox{doubles} + 3 \times \mbox{triples} + 4 \times \mbox{HR}\). Let's see how these coefficients compare to those obtained with regression. Fit a regression model to the data after 1961, as done earlier: using per game statistics for each year for each team. After fitting this model, report the coefficients as weights relative to the coefficient for singles.

6. We see that our linear regression model coefficients follow the same general trend as those used by OPS, but with slightly less weight for metrics other than singles. For each team in years after 1961, compute the OPS, the predicted runs with the regression model and compute the correlation between the two as well as the correlation with runs per game.

7. We see that using the regression approach predicts runs slightly better than OPS, but not that much. However, note that we have been computing OPS and predicting runs for teams when these measures are used to evaluate players. Let's show that OPS is quite similar to what one obtains with regression at the player level. For the 1961 season and after, compute the OPS and the predicted runs from our model for each player and plot them. Use the PA per game correction we used in the previous chapter:

8. What players have show the largest difference between their rank by predicted runs and OPS?

\hypertarget{association-is-not-causation}{%
\chapter{Association is not causation}\label{association-is-not-causation}}

\emph{Association is not causation} is perhaps the most important lesson one learns in a statistics class. \emph{Correlation is not causation} is another way to say this. Throughout the Statistics part of the book, we have described tools useful for quantifying associations between variables. However, we must be careful not to over-interpret these associations.

There are many reasons that a variable \(X\) can be correlated with a variable \(Y\) without having any direct effect on \(Y\). Here we examine four common ways that can lead to misinterpreting data.

\hypertarget{spurious-correlation}{%
\section{Spurious correlation}\label{spurious-correlation}}

The following comical example underscores that correlation is not causation. It shows a very strong correlation between divorce rates and margarine consumption.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\NormalTok{the_title <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Correlation ="}\NormalTok{, }
                \KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{with}\NormalTok{(divorce_margarine, }
                           \KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(margarine_consumption_per_capita, divorce_rate_maine)),}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(divorce_margarine)}
\NormalTok{divorce_margarine }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(margarine_consumption_per_capita, divorce_rate_maine)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{cex=}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_smooth}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"lm"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(the_title) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{xlab}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Margarine Consumption per Capita (lbs)"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ylab}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Divorce rate in Maine (per 1000)"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/divorce-versus-margarine-1} \end{center}

Does this mean that margarine causes divorces? Or do divorces cause people to eat more margarine? Of course the answer to both these questions is no. This is just an example of what we call a \emph{spurious correlation}.

You can see many more absurd examples on the Spurious Correlations website\footnote{\url{http://tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations}}.

The cases presented in the spurious correlation site are all instances of what is generally called \emph{data dredging}, \emph{data fishing}, or \emph{data snooping}. It's basically a form of what in the US they call \emph{cherry picking}. An example of data dredging would be if you look through many results produced by a random process and pick the one that shows a relationship that supports a theory you want to defend.

A Monte Carlo simulation can be used to show how data dredging can result in finding high correlations among uncorrelated variables. We will save the results of our simulation into a tibble:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{N <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{25}
\NormalTok{g <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1000000}
\NormalTok{sim_data <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{tibble}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{group =} \KeywordTok{rep}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\NormalTok{g, }\DataTypeTok{each=}\NormalTok{N), }
                   \DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(N }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{g), }
                   \DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(N }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{g))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The first column denotes group. We created groups and for each one we generated a pair of independent vectors, \(X\) and \(Y\), with 25 observations each, stored in the second and third columns. Because we constructed the simulation, we know that \(X\) and \(Y\) are not correlated.

Next, we compute the correlation between \texttt{X} and \texttt{Y} for each group and look at the max:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{res <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{sim_data }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(group) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{r =} \KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(x, y)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{desc}\NormalTok{(r))}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\NormalTok{res}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We see a maximum correlation of 0.82 and if you just plot the data from the group achieving this correlation, it shows a convincing plot that \(X\) and \(Y\) are in fact correlated:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{sim_data }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(group }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{res}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{group[}\KeywordTok{which.max}\NormalTok{(res}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{r)]) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, y)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_smooth}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"lm"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/dredging-1} \end{center}

Remember that the correlation summary is a random variable. Here is the distribution generated by the Monte Carlo simulation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{res }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x=}\NormalTok{r)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{geom_histogram}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{binwidth =} \FloatTok{0.1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/null-corr-hist-1} \end{center}

It's just a mathematical fact that if we observe random correlations that are expected to be 0, but have a standard error of 0.204, the largest one will be close to 1.

If we performed regression on this group and interpreted the p-value, we would incorrectly claim this was a statistically significant relation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(broom)}
\NormalTok{sim_data }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(group }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{res}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{group[}\KeywordTok{which.max}\NormalTok{(res}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{r)]) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{do}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ .))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(term }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "x"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This particular form of data dredging is referred to as \emph{p-hacking}. P-hacking is a topic of much discussion because it is a problem in scientific publications. Because publishers tend to reward statistically significant results over negative results, there is an incentive to report significant results. In epidemiology and the social sciences, for example, researchers may look for associations between an adverse outcome and several exposures and report only the one exposure that resulted in a small p-value. Furthermore, they might try fitting several different models to account for confounding and pick the one that yields the smallest p-value. In experimental disciplines, an experiment might be repeated more than once, yet only the results of the one experiment with a small p-value reported. This does not necessarily happen due to unethical behavior, but rather as a result of statistical ignorance or wishful thinking. In advanced statistics courses, you can learn methods to adjust for these multiple comparisons.

\hypertarget{outliers-1}{%
\section{Outliers}\label{outliers-1}}

Suppose we take measurements from two independent outcomes, \(X\) and \(Y\), and we standardize the measurements. However, imagine we make a mistake and forget to standardize entry 23. We can simulate such data using:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1985}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{,}\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{,}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{,}\DecValTok{84}\NormalTok{,}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{x[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{] <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{scale}\NormalTok{(x[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{])}
\NormalTok{y[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{] <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{scale}\NormalTok{(y[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{])}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The data look like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(x, y)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/outlier-1} \end{center}

Not surprisingly, the correlation is very high:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(x,y)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.988}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

But this is driven by the one outlier. If we remove this outlier, the correlation is greatly reduced to almost 0, which is what it should be:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(x[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{], y[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{])}
\CommentTok{#> [1] -0.0442}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In Section \ref{robust-summaries} we described alternatives to the average and standard deviation that are robust to outliers. There is also an alternative to the sample correlation for estimating the population correlation that is robust to outliers. It is called \emph{Spearman correlation}. The idea is simple: compute the correlation on the ranks of the values. Here is a plot of the ranks plotted against each other:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rank}\NormalTok{(x), }\KeywordTok{rank}\NormalTok{(y))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/scatter-plot-of-ranks-1} \end{center}

The outlier is no longer associated with a very large value and the correlation comes way down:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rank}\NormalTok{(x), }\KeywordTok{rank}\NormalTok{(y))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.00251}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Spearman correlation can also be calculated like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(x, y, }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"spearman"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.00251}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

There are also methods for robust fitting of linear models which you can learn about in, for instance, this book: Robust Statistics: Edition 2 by Peter J. Huber \& Elvezio M. Ronchetti.

\hypertarget{reversing-cause-and-effect}{%
\section{Reversing cause and effect}\label{reversing-cause-and-effect}}

Another way association is confused with causation is when the cause and effect are reversed. An example of this is claiming that tutoring makes students perform worse because they test lower than peers that are not tutored. In this case, the tutoring is not causing the low test scores, but the other way around.

A form of this claim actually made it into an op-ed in the New York Times titled Parental Involvement Is Overrated\footnote{\url{https://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/12/parental-involvement-is-overrated}}. Consider this quote from the article:

\begin{quote}
\begin{quote}
When we examined whether regular help with homework had a positive impact on children's academic performance, we were quite startled by what we found. Regardless of a family's social class, racial or ethnic background, or a child's grade level, consistent homework help almost never improved test scores or grades\ldots{} Even more surprising to us was that when parents regularly helped with homework, kids usually performed worse.
\end{quote}
\end{quote}

A very likely possibility is that the children needing regular parental help, receive this help because they don't perform well in school.

We can easily construct an example of cause and effect reversal using the father and son height data. If we fit the model:

\[X_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 y_i + \varepsilon_i, i=1, \dots, N\]

to the father and son height data, with \(X_i\) the father height and \(y_i\) the son height, we do get a statistically significant result:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(HistData)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"GaltonFamilies"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{GaltonFamilies }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(childNum }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{gender }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "male"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(father, childHeight) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{rename}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{son =}\NormalTok{ childHeight) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{do}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(father }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{son, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ .)))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The model fits the data very well. If we look at the mathematical formulation of the model above, it could easily be incorrectly interpreted so as to suggest that the son being tall caused the father to be tall. But given what we know about genetics and biology, we know it's the other way around. The model is technically correct. The estimates and p-values were obtained correctly as well. What is wrong here is the interpretation.

\hypertarget{confounders}{%
\section{Confounders}\label{confounders}}

Confounders are perhaps the most common reason that leads to associations begin misinterpreted.

If \(X\) and \(Y\) are correlated, we call \(Z\) a \emph{confounder} if changes in \(Z\) causes changes in both \(X\) and \(Y\). Earlier, when studying baseball data, we saw how Home Runs was a confounder that resulted in a higher correlation than expected when studying the relationship between Bases on Balls and Runs. In some cases, we can use linear models to account for confounders. However, this is not always the case.

Incorrect interpretation due to confounders is ubiquitous in the lay press and they are often hard to detect. Here, we present a widely used example related to college admissions.

\hypertarget{example-uc-berkeley-admissions}{%
\subsection{Example: UC Berkeley admissions}\label{example-uc-berkeley-admissions}}

Admission data from six U.C. Berkeley majors, from 1973, showed that more men were being admitted than women: 44\% men were admitted compared to 30\% women. PJ Bickel, EA Hammel, and JW O'Connell. Science (1975). We can load the data and
a statistical test, which clearly rejects the hypothesis that gender and admission are independent:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(admissions)}
\NormalTok{admissions }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(gender) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{total_admitted =} \KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(admitted }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{100} \OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{applicants)), }
            \DataTypeTok{not_admitted =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(applicants) }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(total_admitted)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{gender) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{do}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{chisq.test}\NormalTok{(.))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{.}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{p.value}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 1.06e-21}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

But closer inspection shows a paradoxical result. Here are the percent admissions by major:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{admissions }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(major, gender, admitted) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{spread}\NormalTok{(gender, admitted) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{women_minus_men =}\NormalTok{ women }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{men)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Four out of the six majors favor women. More importantly, all the differences are much smaller than the 14.2 difference that we see when examining the totals.

The paradox is that analyzing the totals suggests a dependence between admission and gender, but when the data is grouped by major, this dependence seems to disappear. What's going on? This actually can happen if an uncounted confounder is driving most of the variability.

So let's define three variables: \(X\) is 1 for men and 0 for women, \(Y\) is 1 for those admitted and 0 otherwise, and \(Z\) quantifies the selectivity of the major. A gender bias claim would be based on the fact that \(\mbox{Pr}(Y=1 | X = x)\) is higher for \(x=1\) than \(x=0\). However, \(Z\) is an important confounder to consider. Clearly \(Z\) is associated with \(Y\), as the more selective a major, the lower \(\mbox{Pr}(Y=1 | Z = z)\). But is major selectivity \(Z\) associated with gender \(X\)?

One way to see this is to plot the total percent admitted to a major versus the percent of women that made up the applicants:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{admissions }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(major) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{major_selectivity =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(admitted }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{applicants)}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(applicants),}
            \DataTypeTok{percent_women_applicants =} \KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(applicants }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{(gender}\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{"women"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{/}
\StringTok{                                             }\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(applicants) }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(major_selectivity, percent_women_applicants, }\DataTypeTok{label =}\NormalTok{ major)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_text}\NormalTok{()}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/uc-berkeley-majors-1} \end{center}

There seems to be association. The plot suggests that women were much more likely to apply to the two ``hard'' majors: gender and major's selectivity are confounded. Compare, for example, major B and major E. Major E is much harder to enter than major B and over 60\% of applicants to major E were women, while less than 30\% of the applicants of major B were women.

\hypertarget{confounding-explained-graphically}{%
\subsection{Confounding explained graphically}\label{confounding-explained-graphically}}

The following plot shows the number of applicants that were admitted and those that were not by:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{admissions }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{yes =} \KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(admitted}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{100}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{applicants), }\DataTypeTok{no =}\NormalTok{ applicants }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{yes) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{applicants, }\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{admitted) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{gather}\NormalTok{(admission, number_of_students, }\OperatorTok{-}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"major"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"gender"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(gender, number_of_students, }\DataTypeTok{fill =}\NormalTok{ admission)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_bar}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{stat =} \StringTok{"identity"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{position =} \StringTok{"stack"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{facet_wrap}\NormalTok{(. }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{major)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/confounding-1} \end{center}

It also breaks down the acceptances by major. This breakdown allows us to see that the majority of accepted men came from two majors: A and B. It also lets us see that few women applied to these majors.

\hypertarget{average-after-stratifying}{%
\subsection{Average after stratifying}\label{average-after-stratifying}}

In this plot, we can see that if we condition or stratify by major, and then look at differences, we control for the confounder and this effect goes away:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{admissions }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(major, admitted, }\DataTypeTok{col =}\NormalTok{ gender, }\DataTypeTok{size =}\NormalTok{ applicants)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/admission-by-major-1} \end{center}

Now we see that major by major, there is not much difference. The size of the dot represents the number of applicants, and explains the paradox: we see large red dots and small blue dots for the easiest majors, A and B.

If we average the difference by major, we find that the percent is actually 3.5\% higher for women.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{admissions }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(gender) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{average =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(admitted))}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{simpsons-paradox}{%
\section{Simpson's paradox}\label{simpsons-paradox}}

The case we have just covered is an example of Simpson's paradox. It is called a paradox because we see the sign of the correlation flip when comparing the entire publication and specific strata. As an illustrative example, suppose you have three random variables \(X\), \(Y\), and \(Z\) and that we observe realizations of these. Here is a plot of simulated observations for \(X\) and \(Y\) along with the sample correlation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{N <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{100}
\NormalTok{Sigma <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{,}\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{,}\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}\OperatorTok{*}\FloatTok{1.5}
\NormalTok{means <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{list}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{), }
              \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{), }
              \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{), }
              \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{), }
              \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{lapply}\NormalTok{(means, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(mu)\{}
\NormalTok{  res <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{MASS}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{mvrnorm}\NormalTok{(N, mu, Sigma)}
  \KeywordTok{colnames}\NormalTok{(res) <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"x"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"y"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  res}
\NormalTok{\})}

\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{do.call}\NormalTok{(rbind, dat) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{as_tibble}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{z =} \KeywordTok{as.character}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rep}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{seq_along}\NormalTok{(means), }\DataTypeTok{each =}\NormalTok{ N)))}

\NormalTok{dat }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, y)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Correlation = "}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(dat}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x, dat}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y), }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/simpsons-paradox-1} \end{center}

You can see that \(X\) and \(Y\) are negatively correlated. However, once we stratify by \(Z\) (shown in different colors below) another pattern emerges:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{means <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{do.call}\NormalTok{(rbind, means) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{as_tibble}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{z =} \KeywordTok{as.character}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{seq_along}\NormalTok{(means)))}
  
\NormalTok{corrs <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{dat }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(z) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{cor =} \KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(x, y)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{pull}\NormalTok{(cor)}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}

\NormalTok{dat }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, y, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ z)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Correlations ="}\NormalTok{,  }\KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{signif}\NormalTok{(corrs,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{collapse=}\StringTok{" "}\NormalTok{))) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{annotate}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"text"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ means}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x, }\DataTypeTok{y =}\NormalTok{ means}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y, }\DataTypeTok{label =} \KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"z ="}\NormalTok{, means}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{z), }\DataTypeTok{cex =} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)  }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/simpsons-paradox-explained-1} \end{center}

It is really \(Z\) that is negatively correlated with \(X\). If we stratify by \(Z\), the \(X\) and \(Y\) are actually positively correlated as seen in the plot above.

\hypertarget{exercises-37}{%
\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-37}}

For the next set of exercises, we examine the data from a 2014 PNAS paper\footnote{\url{http://www.pnas.org/content/112/40/12349.abstract}} that analyzed success rates from funding agencies in the Netherlands and concluded:

\begin{quote}
Our results reveal gender bias favoring male applicants over female applicants in the prioritization of their ``quality of researcher'' (but not ``quality of proposal'') evaluations and success rates, as well as in the language used in instructional and evaluation materials.
\end{quote}

A response\footnote{\url{http://www.pnas.org/content/112/51/E7036.extract}} was published a few months later titled \emph{No evidence that gender contributes to personal research funding success in The Netherlands: A reaction to Van der Lee and Ellemers} which concluded:

\begin{quote}
However, the overall gender effect borders on statistical significance, despite the large sample. Moreover, their conclusion could be a prime example of Simpson's paradox; if a higher percentage of women apply for grants in more competitive scientific disciplines (i.e., with low application success rates for both men and women), then an analysis across all disciplines could incorrectly show ``evidence'' of gender inequality.
\end{quote}

Who is right here? The original paper or the response? Here, you will examine the data and come to your own conclusion.

1. The main evidence for the conclusion of the original paper comes down to a comparison of the percentages. Table S1 in the paper includes the information we need:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"research_funding_rates"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{research_funding_rates}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Construct the two-by-two table used for the conclusion about differences in awards by gender.

2. Compute the difference in percentage from the two-by-two table.

3. In the previous exercise, we noticed that the success rate is lower for women. But is it significant? Compute a p-value using a Chi-square test.

4. We see that the p-value is about 0.05. So there appears to be some evidence of an association. But can we infer causation here? Is gender bias causing this observed difference? The response to the original paper claims that what we see here is similar to the UC Berkeley admissions example. Specifically they state that this ``could be a prime example of Simpson's paradox; if a higher percentage of women apply for grants in more competitive scientific disciplines, then an analysis across all disciplines could incorrectly show `evidence' of gender inequality.'' To settle this dispute, create a dataset with number of applications, awards, and success rate for each gender. Re-order the disciplines by their overall success rate. Hint: use the \texttt{reorder} function to re-order the disciplines in a first step, then use \texttt{gather}, \texttt{separate}, and \texttt{spread} to create the desired table.

5. To check if this is a case of Simpson's paradox, plot the success rates versus disciplines, which have been ordered by overall success, with colors to denote the genders and size to denote the number of applications.

6. We definitely do not see the same level of confounding as in the UC Berkeley example. It is hard to say there is a confounder here. However, we do see that, based on the observed rates, some fields favor men and others favor women and we do see that the two fields with the largest difference favoring men are also the fields with the most applications. But, unlike the UC Berkeley example, women are not more likely to apply for the harder subjects. So perhaps some of the selection committees are biased and others are not.

But, before we conclude this, we must check if these differences are any different than what we get by chance. Are any of the differences seen above statistically significant? Keep in mind that even when there is no bias, we will see differences due to random variability in the review process as well as random variability across candidates. Perform a Chi-square test for each discipline. Hint: define a function that receives the total of a two-by-two table and returns a data frame with the p-value. Use the 0.5 correction. Then use the do function.

7. For the medical sciences, there appears to be a statistically significant difference. But is this a spurious correlation? We performed 9 tests. Reporting only the one case with a p-value less than 0.05 might be considered an example of cherry picking.
Repeat the exercise above, but instead of a p-value, compute a log odds ratio divided by their standard error. Then use qq-plot to see how much these log odds ratios deviate from the normal distribution we would expect: a standard normal distribution.

\hypertarget{part-data-wrangling}{%
\part{Data Wrangling}\label{part-data-wrangling}}

\hypertarget{introduction-to-data-wrangling}{%
\chapter{Introduction to data wrangling}\label{introduction-to-data-wrangling}}

The datasets used in this book have been made available to you as R objects, specifically as data frames. The US murders data, the reported heights data, and the Gapminder data were all data frames. These datasets come included in the \textbf{dslabs} package and we loaded them using the \texttt{data} function. Furthermore, we have made the data available in what is referred to as \texttt{tidy} form. The tidyverse packages and functions assume that the data is \texttt{tidy} and this assumption is a big part of the reason these packages work so well together.

However, very rarely in a data science project is data easily available as part of a package. We did quite a bit of work ``behind the scenes'' to get the original raw data into the \emph{tidy} tables you worked with. Much more typical is for the data to be in a file, a database, or extracted from a document, including web pages, tweets, or PDFs. In these cases, the first step is to import the data into R and, when using the \textbf{tidyverse}, tidy the data. This initial step in the data analysis process usually involves several, often complicated, steps to convert data from its raw form to the \emph{tidy} form that greatly facilitates the rest of the analysis. We refer to this process as \texttt{data\ wrangling}.

Here we cover several common steps of the data wrangling process including tidying data, string processing, html parsing, working with dates and times, and text mining. Rarely are all these wrangling steps necessary in a single analysis, but data scientists will likely face them all at some point. Some of the examples we use to demonstrate data wrangling techniques are based on the work we did to convert raw data into the tidy datasets provided by the \textbf{dslabs} package and used in the book as examples.

\hypertarget{reshaping-data}{%
\chapter{Reshaping data}\label{reshaping-data}}

As we have seen through the book, having data in \emph{tidy} format is what makes the tidyverse flow. After the first step in the data analysis process, importing data, a common next step is to reshape the data into a form that facilitates the rest of the analysis. The \textbf{tidyr} package includes several functions that are useful for tidying data.

We will use the fertility wide format dataset described in Section \ref{tidy-data} as an example in this section.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse) }
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\NormalTok{path <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{system.file}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"extdata"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{package=}\StringTok{"dslabs"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{filename <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{file.path}\NormalTok{(path, }\StringTok{"fertility-two-countries-example.csv"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{wide_data <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{read_csv}\NormalTok{(filename)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{gather}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{\texttt{gather}}{gather}}\label{gather}}

One of the most used functions in the \textbf{tidyr} package is \texttt{gather}, which is useful for converting wide data into tidy data.

As with most tidyverse functions, the \texttt{gather} function's first argument is the data frame that will be converted. Here we want to reshape the \texttt{wide\_data} dataset so that each row represents a fertility observation, which implies we need three columns to store the year, country, and the observed value. In its current form, data from different years are in different columns with the year values stored in the column names. Through the second and third argument we will tell \texttt{gather} the column names we want to assign to the columns containing the current column names and observations, respectively. In this case a good choice for these two arguments would be \texttt{year} and \texttt{fertility}. Note that nowhere in the data file does it tell us this is fertility data. Instead, we deciphered this from the file name. Through the fourth argument we specify the columns containing observed values; these are the columns that will be \emph{gathered}. The default is to gather all columns so, in most cases, we have to specify the columns. In our example we want columns \texttt{1960}, \texttt{1961} up to \texttt{2015}.

The code to gather the fertility data therefore looks like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_tidy_data <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{gather}\NormalTok{(wide_data, year, fertility, }\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{1960}\StringTok{`}\OperatorTok{:}\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2015}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can also use the pipe like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_tidy_data <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{wide_data }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{gather}\NormalTok{(year, fertility, }\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{1960}\StringTok{`}\OperatorTok{:}\StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{2015}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
