The backslash is used to distinguish it from the character \texttt{d}. In R, we have to \emph{escape} the backslash \texttt{\textbackslash{}} so we actually have to use \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d} to represent digits. Here is an example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5'10"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5 feet"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"4'11"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"."}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Five"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"six"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d"}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(s, pattern)}
\CommentTok{#> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We take this opportunity to introduce the \texttt{str\_view} function, which is helpful for troubleshooting as it shows us the first match for each string:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_view}\NormalTok{(s, pattern)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{wrangling/img//str_view-1} \end{center}

and \texttt{str\_view\_all} shows us all the matches, so \texttt{3\textquotesingle{}2} has two matches and \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}10} has three.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_view_all}\NormalTok{(s, pattern)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{wrangling/img//str_view-2} \end{center}

There are many other special characters. We will learn some others below, but you can see most or all of them in the cheat sheet\footnote{\url{https://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/RegExCheatsheet.pdf}} mentioned earlier.

\hypertarget{character-classes}{%
\subsection{Character classes}\label{character-classes}}

Character classes are used to define a series of characters that can be matched. We define character classes with square brackets \texttt{{[}{]}}. So, for example, if we want the pattern to match only if we have a \texttt{5} or a \texttt{6}, we use the regex \texttt{{[}56{]}}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_view}\NormalTok{(s, }\StringTok{"[56]"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{wrangling/img//str_view-3} \end{center}

Suppose we want to match values between 4 and 7. A common way to define character classes is with ranges. So, for example, \texttt{{[}0-9{]}} is equivalent to \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d}. The pattern we want is therefore \texttt{{[}4-7{]}}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.character}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{4}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.character}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(s, }\StringTok{"[4-7]"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, it is important to know that in regex everything is a character; there are no numbers. So \texttt{4} is the character \texttt{4} not the number four. Notice, for example, that \texttt{{[}1-20{]}} does \textbf{not} mean 1 through 20, it means the characters 1 through 2 or the character 0. So \texttt{{[}1-20{]}} simply means the character class composed of 0, 1, and 2.

Keep in mind that characters do have an order and the digits do follow the numeric order. So \texttt{0} comes before \texttt{1} which comes before \texttt{2} and so on. For the same reason, we can define lower case letters as \texttt{{[}a-z{]}}, upper case letters as \texttt{{[}A-Z{]}}, and \texttt{{[}a-zA-z{]}} as both.

\hypertarget{anchors}{%
\subsection{Anchors}\label{anchors}}

What if we want a match when we have exactly 1 digit? This will be useful in our case study since feet are never more than 1 digit so a restriction will help us. One way to do this with regex is by using \emph{anchors}, which let us define patterns that must start or end at a specific place. The two most common anchors are
\texttt{\^{}} and \texttt{\$} which represent the beginning and end of a string, respectively. So the pattern \texttt{\^{}\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d\$} is read as ``start of the string followed by one digit followed by end of string''.

This pattern now only detects the strings with exactly one digit:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d$"}
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"9"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"12"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"123"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{" 1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a4"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\KeywordTok{str_view_all}\NormalTok{(s, pattern)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d$"}
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"9"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"12"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"123"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{" 1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a4"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\NormalTok{knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{include_graphics}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{file.path}\NormalTok{(img_path,}\StringTok{"str_view-4.png"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{wrangling/img//str_view-4} \end{center}

The \texttt{1} does not match because it does not start with the digit but rather with a space, which is actually not easy to see.

\hypertarget{quantifiers}{%
\subsection{Quantifiers}\label{quantifiers}}

For the inches part, we can have one or two digits. This can be specified in regex with \emph{quantifiers}. This is done by following the pattern with curly brackets containing the number of times the previous entry can be repeated. We use an example to illustrate. The pattern for one or two digits is:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\}$"}
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"9"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"12"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"123"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"a4"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"b"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{str_view}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no), pattern)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{wrangling/img//str_view-5} \end{center}

In this case, \texttt{123} does \textbf{not} match, but \texttt{12} does. So to look for our feet and inches pattern, we can add the symbols for feet \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} and inches \texttt{"} after the digits.

With what we have learned, we can now construct an example for the pattern \texttt{x\textquotesingle{}y\textbackslash{}"} with \texttt{x} feet and \texttt{y} inches.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{$"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The pattern is now getting complex, but you can look at it carefully and break it down:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \texttt{\^{}} = start of the string
\item
  \texttt{{[}4-7{]}} = one digit, either 4,5,6 or 7
\item
  \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} = feet symbol
\item
  \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d\{1,2\}} = one or two digits
\item
  \texttt{\textbackslash{}"} = inches symbol
\item
  \texttt{\$} = end of the string
\end{itemize}

Let's test it out:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5'7}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6'2}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{,  }\StringTok{"5'12}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"6,2}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6.2}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"I am 5'11}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"3'2}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"64"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(yes, pattern)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(no, pattern)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

For now, we are permitting the inches to be 12 or larger. We will add a restriction later as the regex for this is a bit more complex than we are ready to show.

\hypertarget{white-space-s}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{White space \texttt{\textbackslash{}s}}{White space \textbackslash s}}\label{white-space-s}}

Another problem we have are spaces. For example, our pattern does not match \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}\ 4"} because there is a space between \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} and \texttt{4} which our pattern does not permit. Spaces are characters and R does not ignore them:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{identical}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hi "}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In regex, \texttt{\textbackslash{}s} represents white space. To find patterns like \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}\ 4}, we can change our pattern to:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{$"}
\KeywordTok{str_subset}\NormalTok{(problems, pattern_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5' 4\textbackslash{}""  "5' 11\textbackslash{}"" "5' 7\textbackslash{}""}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, this will not match the patterns with no space. So do we need more than one regex pattern? It turns out we can use a quantifier for this as well.

\hypertarget{quantifiers-1}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{Quantifiers: \texttt{*}, \texttt{?}, \texttt{+}}{Quantifiers: *, ?, +}}\label{quantifiers-1}}

We want the pattern to permit spaces but not require them. Even if there are several spaces, like in this example \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}\ \ \ 4}, we still want it to match. There is a quantifier for exactly this purpose. In regex, the character \texttt{*} means zero or more instances of the previous character. Here is an example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"AB"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A1B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A11B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A111B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A1111B"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"A2B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A21B"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(yes, }\StringTok{"A1*B"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(no, }\StringTok{"A1*B"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] FALSE FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The above matches the first string which has zero 1s and all the strings with one or more 1. We can then improve our pattern by adding the \texttt{*} after the space character \texttt{\textbackslash{}s}.

There are two other similar quantifiers. For none or once, we can use \texttt{?}, and for one or more, we can use \texttt{+}. You can see how they differ with this example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{string =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"AB"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A1B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A11B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A111B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"A1111B"}\NormalTok{),}
           \DataTypeTok{none_or_more =} \KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(yes, }\StringTok{"A1*B"}\NormalTok{),}
           \DataTypeTok{nore_or_once =} \KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(yes, }\StringTok{"A1?B"}\NormalTok{),}
           \DataTypeTok{once_or_more =} \KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(yes, }\StringTok{"A1+B"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We will actually use all three in our reported heights example, but we will see these in a later section.

\hypertarget{not}{%
\subsection{Not}\label{not}}

To specify patterns that we do \textbf{not} want to detect, we can use the \texttt{\^{}} symbol but only \textbf{inside} square brackets. Remember that outside the square bracket \texttt{\^{}} means the start of the string. So, for example, if we want to detect digits that are preceded by anything except a letter we can do the following:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "[^a-zA-Z]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d"}
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{".3"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"+2"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"-0"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"*4"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"A3"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"B2"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"C0"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"E4"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(yes, pattern)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(no, pattern)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Another way to generate a pattern that searches for \emph{everything except} is to use the upper case of the special character. For example \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}D} means anything other than a digit, \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}S} means anything except a space, and so on.

\hypertarget{groups}{%
\subsection{Groups}\label{groups}}

\emph{Groups} are a powerful aspect of regex that permits the extraction of values. Groups are defined using parentheses. They don't affect the pattern matching per se. Instead, it permits tools to identify specific parts of the pattern so we can extract them.

We want to change heights written like \texttt{5.6} to \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}6}.

To avoid changing patterns such as \texttt{70.2}, we will require that the first digit be between 4 and 7 \texttt{{[}4-7{]}} and that the second be none or more digits \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d*}.
Let's start by defining a simple pattern that matches this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern_without_groups <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7],}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*$"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We want to extract the digits so we can then form the new version using a period. These are our two groups, so we encapsulate them with parentheses:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern_with_groups <-}\StringTok{  "^([4-7]),(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We encapsulate the part of the pattern that matches the parts we want to keep for later use. Adding groups does not affect the detection, since it only signals that we want to save what is captured by the groups. Note that both patterns return the same result when using \texttt{str\_detect}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5,9"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5,11"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6,"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6,1"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5'9"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{","}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"2,8"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6.1.1"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(s, pattern_without_groups)}
\CommentTok{#> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE}
\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(s, pattern_with_groups)}
\CommentTok{#> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Once we define groups, we can use the function \texttt{str\_match} to extract the values these groups define:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_match}\NormalTok{(s, pattern_with_groups)}
\CommentTok{#>      [,1]   [,2] [,3]}
\CommentTok{#> [1,] "5,9"  "5"  "9" }
\CommentTok{#> [2,] "5,11" "5"  "11"}
\CommentTok{#> [3,] "6,"   "6"  ""  }
\CommentTok{#> [4,] "6,1"  "6"  "1" }
\CommentTok{#> [5,] NA     NA   NA  }
\CommentTok{#> [6,] NA     NA   NA  }
\CommentTok{#> [7,] NA     NA   NA  }
\CommentTok{#> [8,] NA     NA   NA}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Notice that the second and third columns contain feet and inches, respectively. The first column is the part of the string matching the pattern. If no match occurred, we see an \texttt{NA}.

Now we can understand the difference between the functions \texttt{str\_extract} and \texttt{str\_match}: \texttt{str\_extract} extracts only strings that match a pattern, not the values defined by groups:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_extract}\NormalTok{(s, pattern_with_groups)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5,9"  "5,11" "6,"   "6,1"  NA     NA     NA     NA}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{search-and-replace-with-regex}{%
\section{Search and replace with regex}\label{search-and-replace-with-regex}}

Earlier we defined the object \texttt{problems} containing the strings that do not appear to be in inches. We can see that not too many of our problematic strings match the pattern:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{$"}
\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(problems, pattern))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 14}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To see why this is, we show some examples that expose why we don't have more matches:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{problems[}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{12}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{15}\NormalTok{)] }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_view}\NormalTok{(pattern)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{wrangling/img//str_view-6} \end{center}

An initial problem we see immediately is that some students wrote out the words ``feet'' and ``inches''. We can see the entries that did this with the \texttt{str\_subset} function:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_subset}\NormalTok{(problems, }\StringTok{"inches"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5 feet and 8.11 inches" "Five foot eight inches"}
\CommentTok{#> [3] "5 feet 7inches"         "5ft 9 inches"          }
\CommentTok{#> [5] "5 ft 9 inches"          "5 feet 6 inches"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We also see that some entries used two single quotes \texttt{\textquotesingle{}\textquotesingle{}} instead of a double quote \texttt{"}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_subset}\NormalTok{(problems, }\StringTok{"''"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#>  [1] "5'9''"   "5'10''"  "5'10''"  "5'3''"   "5'7''"   "5'6''"  }
\CommentTok{#>  [7] "5'7.5''" "5'7.5''" "5'10''"  "5'11''"  "5'10''"  "5'5''"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To correct this, we can replace the different ways of representing inches and feet with a uniform symbol. We will use \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} for feet, whereas for inches we will simply not use a symbol since some entries were of the form \texttt{x\textquotesingle{}y}. Now, if we no longer use the inches symbol, we have to change our pattern accordingly:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\}$"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If we do this replacement before the matching, we get many more matches:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{problems }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet|ft|foot"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"'"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\CommentTok{# replace feet, ft, foot with ' }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"inches|in|''|}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\CommentTok{# remove all inches symbols}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(pattern) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{()}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 48}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, we still have many cases to go.

Note that in the code above, we leveraged the \textbf{stringr} consistency and used the pipe.

For now, we improve our pattern by adding \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s*} in front of and after the feet symbol \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} to permit space between the feet symbol and the numbers. Now we match a few more entries:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\}$"}
\NormalTok{problems }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet|ft|foot"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"'"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\CommentTok{# replace feet, ft, foot with ' }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"inches|in|''|}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\CommentTok{# remove all inches symbols}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(pattern) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\NormalTok{sum}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 53}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We might be tempted to avoid doing this by removing all the spaces with \texttt{str\_replace\_all}. However, when doing such an operation we need to make sure that it does not have unintended effects. In our reported heights examples, this will be a problem because some entries are of the form \texttt{x\ y} with space separating the feet from the inches. If we remove all spaces, we will incorrectly turn \texttt{x\ y} into \texttt{xy} which implies that a \texttt{6\ 1} would become \texttt{61} inches instead of \texttt{73} inches.

The second large type of problematic entries were of the form \texttt{x.y}, \texttt{x,y} and \texttt{x\ y}. We want to change all these to our common format \texttt{x\textquotesingle{}y}. But we can't just do a search and replace because we would change values such as \texttt{70.5} into \texttt{70\textquotesingle{}5}.
Our strategy will therefore be to search for a very specific pattern that assures us feet and inches are being provided and then, for those that match, replace appropriately.

\hypertarget{search-and-replace-using-groups}{%
\subsection{Search and replace using groups}\label{search-and-replace-using-groups}}

Another powerful aspect of groups is that you can refer to the extracted values in a regex when searching and replacing.

The regex special character for the \texttt{i}-th group is \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}i}. So \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}1} is the value extracted from the first group, \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}2} the value from the second and so on. As a simple example, note that the following code will replace a comma with period, but only if it is between two digits:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern_with_groups <-}\StringTok{  "^([4-7]),(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5,9"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5,11"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6,"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6,1"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5'9"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{","}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"2,8"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6.1.1"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(s, pattern_with_groups, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{2"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5'9"   "5'11"  "6'"    "6'1"   "5'9"   ","     "2,8"   "6.1.1"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can use this to convert cases in our reported heights.

We are now ready to define a pattern that helps us convert all the \texttt{x.y}, \texttt{x,y} and \texttt{x\ y} to our preferred format. We need to adapt \texttt{pattern\_with\_groups} to be a bit more flexible and capture all the cases.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern_with_groups <-}\StringTok{"^([4-7])}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*[,}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s+]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Let's break this one down:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \texttt{\^{}} = start of the string
\item
  \texttt{{[}4-7{]}} = one digit, either 4, 5, 6, or 7
\item
  \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s*} = none or more white space
\item
  \texttt{{[},\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}.\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s+{]}} = feet symbol is either \texttt{,}, \texttt{.} or at least one space
\item
  \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s*} = none or more white space
\item
  \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d*} = none or more digits
\item
  \texttt{\$} = end of the string
\end{itemize}

We can see that it appears to be working:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_subset}\NormalTok{(problems, pattern_with_groups) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{head}\NormalTok{()}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5.3"  "5.25" "5.5"  "6.5"  "5.8"  "5.6"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

and will be able to perform the search and replace:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_subset}\NormalTok{(problems, pattern_with_groups) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(pattern_with_groups, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{2"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{head}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5'3"  "5'25" "5'5"  "6'5"  "5'8"  "5'6"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Again, we will deal with the inches-larger-than-twelve challenge later.

\hypertarget{testing-and-improving}{%
\section{Testing and improving}\label{testing-and-improving}}

Developing the right regex on the first try is often difficult. Trial and error is a common approach to finding the regex pattern that satisfies all desired conditions. In the previous sections, we have developed a powerful string processing technique that can help us catch many of the problematic entries. Here we will test our approach, search for further problems, and tweak our approach for possible improvements. Let's write a function that captures all the entries that can't be converted into numbers remembering that some are in centimeters (we will deal with those later):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{not_inches_or_cm <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{smallest =} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{tallest =} \DecValTok{84}\NormalTok{)\{}
\NormalTok{  inches <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{suppressWarnings}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{as.numeric}\NormalTok{(x))}
\NormalTok{  ind <-}\StringTok{ }\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(inches) }\OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{    }\NormalTok{((inches }\OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{smallest }\OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{inches }\OperatorTok{<=}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{tallest) }\OperatorTok{|}
\StringTok{       }\NormalTok{(inches}\OperatorTok{/}\FloatTok{2.54} \OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{smallest }\OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{inches}\OperatorTok{/}\FloatTok{2.54} \OperatorTok{<=}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{tallest))}
  \OperatorTok{!}\NormalTok{ind}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{problems <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{reported_heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{not_inches_or_cm}\NormalTok{(height)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{pull}\NormalTok{(height)}
\KeywordTok{length}\NormalTok{(problems)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 200}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Let's see what proportion of these fit our pattern after the processing steps we developed above:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{converted <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{problems }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet|foot|ft"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"'"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\CommentTok{# convert feet symbols to '}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"inches|in|''|}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }\CommentTok{# remove inches symbols}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"^([4-7])}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*[,}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s+]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{2"}\NormalTok{)}\CommentTok{# change format}

\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\}$"}
\NormalTok{index <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(converted, pattern)}
\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(index)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.615}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note how we leveraged the pipe, one of the advantages of using \textbf{stringr}. This last piece of code shows that we have matched well over half of the strings. Let's examine the remaining cases:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{converted[}\OperatorTok{!}\NormalTok{index]}
\CommentTok{#>  [1] "6"             "165cm"         "511"           "6"            }
\CommentTok{#>  [5] "2"             ">9000"         "5 ' and 8.11 " "11111"        }
\CommentTok{#>  [9] "6"             "103.2"         "19"            "5"            }
\CommentTok{#> [13] "300"           "6'"            "6"             "Five ' eight "}
\CommentTok{#> [17] "7"             "214"           "6"             "0.7"          }
\CommentTok{#> [21] "6"             "2'33"          "612"           "1,70"         }
\CommentTok{#> [25] "87"            "5'7.5"         "5'7.5"         "111"          }
\CommentTok{#> [29] "5' 7.78"       "12"            "6"             "yyy"          }
\CommentTok{#> [33] "89"            "34"            "25"            "6"            }
\CommentTok{#> [37] "6"             "22"            "684"           "6"            }
\CommentTok{#> [41] "1"             "1"             "6*12"          "87"           }
\CommentTok{#> [45] "6"             "1.6"           "120"           "120"          }
\CommentTok{#> [49] "23"            "1.7"           "6"             "5"            }
\CommentTok{#> [53] "69"            "5' 9 "         "5 ' 9 "        "6"            }
\CommentTok{#> [57] "6"             "86"            "708,661"       "5 ' 6 "       }
\CommentTok{#> [61] "6"             "649,606"       "10000"         "1"            }
\CommentTok{#> [65] "728,346"       "0"             "6"             "6"            }
\CommentTok{#> [69] "6"             "100"           "88"            "6"            }
\CommentTok{#> [73] "170 cm"        "7,283,465"     "5"             "5"            }
\CommentTok{#> [77] "34"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Four clear patterns arise:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Many students measuring exactly 5 or 6 feet did not enter any inches, for example \texttt{6\textquotesingle{}}, and our pattern requires that inches be included.
\item
  Some students measuring exactly 5 or 6 feet entered just that number.
\item
  Some of the inches were entered with decimal points. For example \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}7.5\textquotesingle{}\textquotesingle{}}. Our pattern only looks for two digits.
\item
  Some entries have spaces at the end, for example \texttt{5\ \textquotesingle{}\ 9}.
\end{enumerate}

Although not as common, we also see the following problems:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\setcounter{enumi}{4}
\tightlist
\item
  Some entries are in meters and some of these use European decimals: \texttt{1.6}, \texttt{1,70}.
\item
  Two students added \texttt{cm}.
\item
  A student spelled out the numbers: \texttt{Five\ foot\ eight\ inches}.
\end{enumerate}

It is not necessarily clear that it is worth writing code to handle these last three cases since they might be rare enough. However, some of them provide us with an opportunity to learn a few more regex techniques, so we will build a fix.

For case 1, if we add a \texttt{\textquotesingle{}0} after the first digit, for example, convert all \texttt{6} to \texttt{6\textquotesingle{}0}, then our previously defined pattern will match. This can be done using groups:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5'"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5''"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5'4"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(s, }\StringTok{"^([4-7])$"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1'0"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5'0" "6'0" "5'0" "5'"  "5''" "5'4"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The pattern says it has to start (\texttt{\^{}}) with a digit between 4 and 7 and end there (\texttt{\$}). The parenthesis defines the group that we pass as \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}1} to generate the replacement regex string.

We can adapt this code slightly to handle the case 2 as well, which covers the entry \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}}. Note \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}} is left untouched. This is because the extra \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} makes the pattern not match since we have to end with a 5 or 6. We want to permit the 5 or 6 to be followed by 0 or 1 feet sign. So we can simply add \texttt{\textquotesingle{}\{0,1\}} after the \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} to do this. However, we can use the none or once special character \texttt{?}. As we saw above, this is different from \texttt{*} which is none or more. We now see that the fourth case is also converted:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(s, }\StringTok{"^([56])'?$"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1'0"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5'0" "6'0" "5'0" "5'0" "5''" "5'4"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Here we only permit 5 and 6, but not 4 and 7. This is because 5 and 6 feet tall is quite common, so we assume those that typed 5 or 6 really meant \texttt{60} or \texttt{72} inches. However, \texttt{4} and \texttt{7} feet tall are so rare that, although we accept \texttt{84} as a valid entry, we assume \texttt{7} was entered in error.

We can use quantifiers to deal with \textbf{case 3}. These entries are not matched because the inches include decimals and our pattern does not permit this. We need to allow the second group to include decimals not just digits. This means we must permit zero or one period \texttt{.} then zero or more digits. So we will be using both \texttt{?} and \texttt{*}.
Also remember that, for this particular case, the period needs to be escaped since it is a special character (it means any character except line break). Here is a simple example of how we can use \texttt{*}.

So we can adapt our pattern, currently \texttt{\^{}{[}4-7{]}\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s*\textquotesingle{}\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s*\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d\{1,2\}\$} to permit a decimal at the end:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d+}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.?}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Case 4, meters using commas, we can approach similarly to how we converted the \texttt{x.y} to \texttt{x\textquotesingle{}y}. A difference is that we require that the first digit be 1 or 2:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{yes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"1,7"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"1, 8"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"2, "}\NormalTok{ )}
\NormalTok{no <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5,8"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"5,3,2"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"1.7"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(yes, no)}
\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(s, }\StringTok{"^([12])}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*,}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{2"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "1.7"   "1.8"   "2."    "5,8"   "5,3,2" "1.7"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We will later check if the entries are meters using their numeric values. We will come back to the case study after introducing two widely used functions in string processing that will come in handy when developing our final solution for the self-reported heights.

\hypertarget{trimming}{%
\section{Trimming}\label{trimming}}

In general, spaces at the start or end of the string are uninformative.
These can be particularly deceptive because sometimes they can be hard to see:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ "Hi "}
\KeywordTok{cat}\NormalTok{(s)}
\CommentTok{#> Hi}
\KeywordTok{identical}\NormalTok{(s, }\StringTok{"Hi"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] FALSE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This is a general enough problem that there is a function dedicated to removing them:
\texttt{str\_trim}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{str_trim}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5 ' 9 "}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "5 ' 9"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{changing-lettercase}{%
\section{Changing lettercase}\label{changing-lettercase}}

Notice that regex is case sensitive. Often we want to match a word regardless of case. One approach to doing this is to first change everything to lower case and then proceeding ignoring case. As an example, note that one of the entries writes out numbers as words \texttt{Five\ foot\ eight\ inches}. Although not efficient, we could add 13 extra \texttt{str\_replace} calls to convert \texttt{zero} to \texttt{0}, \texttt{one} to \texttt{1}, and so on. To avoid having to write two separate operations for \texttt{Zero} and \texttt{zero}, \texttt{One} and \texttt{one}, etc., we can use the \texttt{str\_to\_lower} function to make all works lower case first:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Five feet eight inches"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{str_to_lower}\NormalTok{(s)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "five feet eight inches"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Other related functions are \texttt{str\_to\_upper} and \texttt{str\_to\_title}. We are now ready to define a procedure that converts all the problematic cases to inches.

\hypertarget{case-study-2-self-reported-heights-continued}{%
\section{Case study 2: self-reported heights (continued)}\label{case-study-2-self-reported-heights-continued}}

We now put all of what we have learned together into a function that takes a string vector and tries to convert as many strings as possible to one format. We write a function that puts together what we have done above.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{convert_format <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(s)\{}
\NormalTok{  s }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet|foot|ft"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"'"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{str_replace_all}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"inches|in|''|}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{|cm|and"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"^([4-7])}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*[,}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s+]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{2"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"^([56])'?$"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1'0"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{str_replace}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"^([12])}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*,}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{1}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{2"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{  }
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{str_trim}\NormalTok{() }
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can also write a function that converts words to numbers:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(english)}
\NormalTok{words_to_numbers <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(s)\{}
\NormalTok{  s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_to_lower}\NormalTok{(s)}
  \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{(i }\ControlFlowTok{in} \DecValTok{0}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_replace_all}\NormalTok{(s, }\KeywordTok{words}\NormalTok{(i), }\KeywordTok{as.character}\NormalTok{(i))}
\NormalTok{  s}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that we can perform the above operation more efficiently with the function \texttt{recode}, which we learn about in Section \ref{recode}.
Now we can see which problematic entries remain:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{converted <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{problems }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{words_to_numbers}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{convert_format}\NormalTok{()}
\NormalTok{remaining_problems <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{converted[}\KeywordTok{not_inches_or_cm}\NormalTok{(converted)]}
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^[4-7]}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d+}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.?}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*$"}
\NormalTok{index <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_detect}\NormalTok{(remaining_problems, pattern)}
\NormalTok{remaining_problems[}\OperatorTok{!}\NormalTok{index]}
\CommentTok{#>  [1] "511"       "2"         ">9000"     "11111"     "103.2"    }
\CommentTok{#>  [6] "19"        "300"       "7"         "214"       "0.7"      }
\CommentTok{#> [11] "2'33"      "612"       "1.70"      "87"        "111"      }
\CommentTok{#> [16] "12"        "yyy"       "89"        "34"        "25"       }
\CommentTok{#> [21] "22"        "684"       "1"         "1"         "6*12"     }
\CommentTok{#> [26] "87"        "1.6"       "120"       "120"       "23"       }
\CommentTok{#> [31] "1.7"       "86"        "708,661"   "649,606"   "10000"    }
\CommentTok{#> [36] "1"         "728,346"   "0"         "100"       "88"       }
\CommentTok{#> [41] "7,283,465" "34"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

apart from the cases reported as meters, which we will fix below, they all seem to be cases that are impossible to fix.

\hypertarget{the-extract-function}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{The \texttt{extract} function}{The extract function}}\label{the-extract-function}}

The \texttt{extract} function is a useful \textbf{tidyverse} function for string processing that we will use in our final solution, so we introduce it here. In a previous section, we constructed a regex that lets us identify which elements of a character vector match the feet and inches pattern. However, we want to do more. We want to extract and save the feet and number values so that we can convert them to inches when appropriate.

If we have a simpler case like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5'10"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6'1"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{tab <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ s)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In Section \ref{separate} we learned about the \texttt{separate} function, which can be used to achieve our current goal:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tab }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{separate}\NormalTok{(x, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"inches"}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{sep =} \StringTok{"'"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{extract} function from the \textbf{tidyr} package lets us use regex groups to extract the desired values. Here is the equivalent to the code above using \texttt{separate} but using \texttt{extract}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyr)}
\NormalTok{tab }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{extract}\NormalTok{(x, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"inches"}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{regex =} \StringTok{"(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d)'(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\})"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

So why do we even need the new function \texttt{extract}? We have seen how small changes can throw off exact pattern matching. Groups in regex give us more flexibility. For example, if we define:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{s <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5'10"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"6'1}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"5'8inches"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{tab <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ s)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

and we only want the numbers, \texttt{separate} fails:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tab }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{separate}\NormalTok{(x, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"inches"}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{sep =} \StringTok{"'"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{fill =} \StringTok{"right"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, we can use \texttt{extract}. The regex here is a bit more complicated since we have to permit \texttt{\textquotesingle{}} with spaces and \texttt{feet}. We also do not want the \texttt{"} included in the value, so we do not include that in the group:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tab }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{extract}\NormalTok{(x, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"inches"}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{regex =} \StringTok{"(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d)'(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d\{1,2\})"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{putting-it-all-together-1}{%
\subsection{Putting it all together}\label{putting-it-all-together-1}}

We are now ready to put it all together and wrangle our reported heights data to try to recover as many heights as possible. The code is complex, but we will break it down into parts.

We start by cleaning up the \texttt{height} column so that the heights are closer to a feet'inches format. We added an original heights column so we can compare before and after.

Now we are ready to wrangle our reported heights dataset:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pattern <-}\StringTok{ "^([4-7])}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*'}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s*(}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d+}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{.?}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{d*)$"}

\NormalTok{smallest <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{50}
\NormalTok{tallest <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{84}
\NormalTok{new_heights <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{reported_heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{original =}\NormalTok{ height, }
         \DataTypeTok{height =} \KeywordTok{words_to_numbers}\NormalTok{(height) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{convert_format}\NormalTok{()) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{extract}\NormalTok{(height, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"feet"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"inches"}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{regex =}\NormalTok{ pattern, }\DataTypeTok{remove =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate_at}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"height"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"feet"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"inches"}\NormalTok{), as.numeric) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{guess =} \DecValTok{12} \OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{feet }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{inches) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{height =} \KeywordTok{case_when}\NormalTok{(}
    \KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(height) }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.numeric}\NormalTok{(}\OtherTok{NA}\NormalTok{),}
    \KeywordTok{between}\NormalTok{(height, smallest, tallest) }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{height,  }\CommentTok{#inches}
    \KeywordTok{between}\NormalTok{(height}\OperatorTok{/}\FloatTok{2.54}\NormalTok{, smallest, tallest) }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{height}\OperatorTok{/}\FloatTok{2.54}\NormalTok{, }\CommentTok{#cm}
    \KeywordTok{between}\NormalTok{(height}\OperatorTok{*}\DecValTok{100}\OperatorTok{/}\FloatTok{2.54}\NormalTok{, smallest, tallest) }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{height}\OperatorTok{*}\DecValTok{100}\OperatorTok{/}\FloatTok{2.54}\NormalTok{, }\CommentTok{#meters}
    \OtherTok{TRUE} \OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as.numeric}\NormalTok{(}\OtherTok{NA}\NormalTok{))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{height =} \KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{is.na}\NormalTok{(height) }\OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{                           }\NormalTok{inches }\OperatorTok{<}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{12} \OperatorTok{&}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{between}\NormalTok{(guess, smallest, tallest),}
\NormalTok{                         guess, height)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{guess)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can check all the entries we converted by typing:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{not_inches}\NormalTok{(original)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(original, height) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(height) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{View}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

A final observation is that if we look at the shortest students in our course:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{arrange}\NormalTok{(height) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{head}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{n=}\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We see heights of 53, 54, and 55. In the originals, we also have 51 and 52. These short heights are rare and it is likely that the students actually meant \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}1}, \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}2}, \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}3}, \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}4}, and \texttt{5\textquotesingle{}5}. Because we are not completely sure, we will leave them as reported. The object \texttt{new\_heights} contains our final solution for this case study.

\hypertarget{string-splitting}{%
\section{String splitting}\label{string-splitting}}

Another very common data wrangling operation is string splitting. To illustrate how this comes up, we start with an illustrative example. Suppose we did not have the function \texttt{read\_csv} or \texttt{read.csv} available to us. We instead have to read a csv file using the base R function \texttt{readLines} like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{filename <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{system.file}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"extdata/murders.csv"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{package =} \StringTok{"dslabs"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{lines <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{readLines}\NormalTok{(filename)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This function reads-in the data line-by-line to create a vector of strings. In this case, one string for each row in the spreadsheet. The first six lines are:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{lines }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{head}\NormalTok{()}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "state,abb,region,population,total"}
\CommentTok{#> [2] "Alabama,AL,South,4779736,135"     }
\CommentTok{#> [3] "Alaska,AK,West,710231,19"         }
\CommentTok{#> [4] "Arizona,AZ,West,6392017,232"      }
\CommentTok{#> [5] "Arkansas,AR,South,2915918,93"     }
\CommentTok{#> [6] "California,CA,West,37253956,1257"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We want to extract the values that are separated by a comma for each string in the vector. The command \texttt{str\_split} does exactly this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_split}\NormalTok{(lines, }\StringTok{","}\NormalTok{) }
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{head}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [[1]]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "state"      "abb"        "region"     "population" "total"     }
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#> [[2]]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "Alabama" "AL"      "South"   "4779736" "135"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that the first entry has the column names, so we can separate that out:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{col_names <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x[[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]]}
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To convert our list into a data frame, we can use a shortcut provided by the \texttt{map} functions in the \textbf{purrr} package. The map function applies the same function to each element in a list. So if we want to extract the first entry of each element in \texttt{x}, we can write:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(purrr)}
\KeywordTok{map}\NormalTok{(x, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(y) y[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{head}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [[1]]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "Alabama"}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#> [[2]]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "Alaska"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, because this is such a common task, \textbf{purrr} provides a shortcut. If the second argument receives an integer instead of a function, it assumes we want that entry. So the code above can be written more efficiently like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{map}\NormalTok{(x, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To force \texttt{map} to return a character vector instead of a list, we can use \texttt{map\_chr}. Similarly, \texttt{map\_int} returns integers. So to create our data frame, we can use:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{tibble}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{map_chr}\NormalTok{(x, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{),  }
              \KeywordTok{map_chr}\NormalTok{(x, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{),}
              \KeywordTok{map_chr}\NormalTok{(x, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{),}
              \KeywordTok{map_chr}\NormalTok{(x, }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{),}
              \KeywordTok{map_chr}\NormalTok{(x, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate_all}\NormalTok{(parse_guess) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(col_names)}
\NormalTok{dat }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{head}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If you learn more about the \textbf{purrr} package, you will learn that you perform the above with the following, more efficient, code:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{transpose}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{map}\NormalTok{( }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{parse_guess}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{unlist}\NormalTok{(.))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(col_names) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{as_tibble}\NormalTok{() }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

It turns out that we can avoid all the work shown above after the call to \texttt{str\_split}. Specifically, if we know that the data we are extracting can be represented as a table, we can use the argument \texttt{simplify=TRUE} and \texttt{str\_split} returns a matrix instead of a list:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_split}\NormalTok{(lines, }\StringTok{","}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{simplify =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{) }
\NormalTok{col_names <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{,]}
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{,]}
\KeywordTok{colnames}\NormalTok{(x) <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{col_names}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as_tibble}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate_all}\NormalTok{(parse_guess) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{head}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{case-study-3-extracting-tables-from-a-pdf}{%
\section{Case study 3: extracting tables from a PDF}\label{case-study-3-extracting-tables-from-a-pdf}}

One of the datasets provided in \textbf{dslabs} shows scientific funding rates by gender in the Netherlands:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"research_funding_rates"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{research_funding_rates }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"discipline"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"success_rates_men"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"success_rates_women"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The data comes from a paper published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science (PNAS)\footnote{\url{http://www.pnas.org/content/112/40/12349.abstract}}, a widely read scientific journal. However, the data is not provided in a spreadsheet; it is in a table in a PDF document. Here is a screenshot of the table:

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.6\linewidth]{wrangling/img//pnas-table-s1} \end{center}

(Source: Romy van der Lee and Naomi Ellemers, PNAS 2015 112 (40) 12349-12353\footnote{\url{http://www.pnas.org/content/112/40/12349}}.)

We could extract the numbers by hand, but this could lead to human error. Instead, we can try to wrangle the data using R. We start by downloading the pdf document, then importing into R:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"pdftools"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{temp_file <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{tempfile}\NormalTok{()}
\NormalTok{url <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{paste0}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"https://www.pnas.org/content/suppl/2015/09/16/"}\NormalTok{,}
              \StringTok{"1510159112.DCSupplemental/pnas.201510159SI.pdf"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{download.file}\NormalTok{(url, temp_file)}
\NormalTok{txt <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{pdf_text}\NormalTok{(temp_file)}
\KeywordTok{file.remove}\NormalTok{(temp_file)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If we examine the object text, we notice that it is a character vector with an entry for each page. So we keep the page we want:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{raw_data_research_funding_rates <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{txt[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The steps above can actually be skipped because we include this raw data in the \textbf{dslabs} package as well:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"raw_data_research_funding_rates"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Examining the object \texttt{raw\_data\_research\_funding\_rates}
we see that it is a long string and each line on the page, including the table rows, are separated by the symbol for newline: \texttt{\textbackslash{}n}. We therefore can create a list with the lines of the text as elements as follows:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tab <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_split}\NormalTok{(raw_data_research_funding_rates, }\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Because we start off with just one element in the string, we end up with a list with just one entry.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tab <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{tab[[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

By examining \texttt{tab} we see that the information for the column names is the third and fourth entries:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{tab[}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{tab[}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The first of these rows looks like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{cat}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{substr}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{options}\NormalTok{()}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{width))}
\CommentTok{#>                                                       Applications, n}
\KeywordTok{cat}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{substr}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{options}\NormalTok{()}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{width, }\KeywordTok{nchar}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)))}
\CommentTok{#>                   Awards, n                      Success rates, %}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We want to create one vector with one name for each column. Using some of the functions we have just learned, we do this. Let's start with \texttt{the\_names\_1}, shown above. We want to remove the leading space and anything following the comma. We use regex for the latter. Then we can obtain the elements by splitting strings separated by space. We want to split only when there are 2 or more spaces to avoid splitting \texttt{Success\ rates}. So we use the regex \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}s\{2,\}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_trim}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace_all}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{",}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s."}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_split}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s\{2,\}"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{simplify =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{1} 
\CommentTok{#>      [,1]           [,2]     [,3]           }
\CommentTok{#> [1,] "Applications" "Awards" "Success rates"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Now we will look at \texttt{the\_names\_2}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{cat}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{substr}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{options}\NormalTok{()}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{width))}
\CommentTok{#>                         Discipline              Total     Men      Women}
\KeywordTok{cat}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{substr}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{options}\NormalTok{()}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{width, }\KeywordTok{nchar}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)))}
\CommentTok{#> n         Total    Men       Women          Total    Men      Women}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Here we want to trim the leading space and then split by space as we did for the first line:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{2} \OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_trim}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_split}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s+"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{simplify =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{the_names_}\DecValTok{2}
\CommentTok{#>      [,1]         [,2]    [,3]  [,4]    [,5]    [,6]  [,7]    [,8]   }
\CommentTok{#> [1,] "Discipline" "Total" "Men" "Women" "Total" "Men" "Women" "Total"}
\CommentTok{#>      [,9]  [,10]  }
\CommentTok{#> [1,] "Men" "Women"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can then join these to generate one name for each column:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tmp_names <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{str_c}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rep}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{each =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{), the_names_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{[}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{], }\DataTypeTok{sep =} \StringTok{"_"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{the_names <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(the_names_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{], tmp_names) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_to_lower}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_replace_all}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"_"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{the_names}
\CommentTok{#>  [1] "discipline"          "applications_total"  "applications_men"   }
\CommentTok{#>  [4] "applications_women"  "awards_total"        "awards_men"         }
\CommentTok{#>  [7] "awards_women"        "success_rates_total" "success_rates_men"  }
\CommentTok{#> [10] "success_rates_women"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Now we are ready to get the actual data. By examining the \texttt{tab} object, we notice that the information is in lines 6 through 14. We can use \texttt{str\_split} again to achieve our goal:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{new_research_funding_rates <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{tab[}\DecValTok{6}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{14}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\NormalTok{str_trim }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{str_split}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{s\{2,\}"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{simplify =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(the_names) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate_at}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, parse_number)}
\NormalTok{new_research_funding_rates }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{as_tibble}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can see that the objects are identical:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{identical}\NormalTok{(research_funding_rates, new_research_funding_rates)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] TRUE}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{recode}{%
\section{Recoding}\label{recode}}

Another common operation involving strings is recoding the names of categorical variables. Let's say you have really long names for your levels and you will be displaying them in plots, you might want to use shorter versions of these names. For example, in character vectors with country names, you might want to change ``United States of America'' to ``USA'' and ``United Kingdom'' to UK, and so on. We can do this with \texttt{case\_when}, although the \textbf{tidyverse} offers an option that is specifically designed for this task: the \texttt{recode} function.

Here is an example that shows how to rename countries with long names:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"gapminder"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Suppose we want to show life expectancy time series by country for the Caribbean:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{gapminder }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(region }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Caribbean"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(year, life_expectancy, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ country)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/caribbean-1} \end{center}

The plot is what we want, but much of the space is wasted to accommodate some of the long country names.
We have four countries with names longer than 12 characters. These names appear once for each year in the Gapminder dataset. Once we pick nicknames, we need to change them all consistently. The \texttt{recode} function can be used to do this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{gapminder }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(region}\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{"Caribbean"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{country =} \KeywordTok{recode}\NormalTok{(country, }
                          \StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{Antigua and Barbuda}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{ =}\StringTok{ "Barbuda"}\NormalTok{,}
                          \StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{Dominican Republic}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{ =}\StringTok{ "DR"}\NormalTok{,}
                          \StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{St. Vincent and the Grenadines}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{ =}\StringTok{ "St. Vincent"}\NormalTok{,}
                          \StringTok{`}\DataTypeTok{Trinidad and Tobago}\StringTok{`}\NormalTok{ =}\StringTok{ "Trinidad"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(year, life_expectancy, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ country)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/caribbean-with-nicknames-1} \end{center}

There are other similar functions in other R packages, such as \texttt{recode\_factor} and \texttt{fct\_recoder} in the \textbf{forcats} package.

\hypertarget{exercises-41}{%
\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-41}}

1. Complete all lessons and exercises in the \url{https://regexone.com/} online interactive tutorial.

2. In the \texttt{extdata} directory of the \textbf{dslabs} package, you will find a PDF file containing daily mortality data for Puerto Rico from Jan 1, 2015 to May 31, 2018. You can find the file like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{system.file}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"extdata"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"RD-Mortality-Report_2015-18-180531.pdf"}\NormalTok{,}
                  \DataTypeTok{package=}\StringTok{"dslabs"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Find and open the file or open it directly from RStudio. On a Mac, you can type:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{system2}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"open"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{args =}\NormalTok{ fn)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

and on Windows, you can type:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{system}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"cmd.exe"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{input =} \KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"start"}\NormalTok{, fn))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Which of the following best describes this file:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\alph{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  It is a table. Extracting the data will be easy.
\item
  It is a report written in prose. Extracting the data will be impossible.
\item
  It is a report combining graphs and tables. Extracting the data seems possible.
\item
  It shows graphs of the data. Extracting the data will be difficult.
\end{enumerate}

3. We are going to create a tidy dataset with each row representing one observation. The variables in this dataset will be year, month, day, and deaths.
Start by installing and loading the \textbf{pdftools} package:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{install.packages}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"pdftools"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(pdftools)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Now read-in \texttt{fn} using the \texttt{pdf\_text} function and store the results in an object called \texttt{txt}. Which of the following best describes what you see in \texttt{txt}?

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\alph{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  A table with the mortality data.
\item
  A character string of length 12. Each entry represents the text in each page. The mortality data is in there somewhere.
\item
  A character string with one entry containing all the information in the PDF file.
\item
  An html document.
\end{enumerate}

4. Extract the ninth page of the PDF file from the object \texttt{txt}, then use the \texttt{str\_split} from the \textbf{stringr} package so that you have each line in a different entry. Call this string vector \texttt{s}. Then look at the result and choose the one that best describes what you see.

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\alph{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  It is an empty string.
\item
  I can see the figure shown in page 1.
\item
  It is a tidy table.
\item
  I can see the table! But there is a bunch of other stuff we need to get rid of.
\end{enumerate}

5. What kind of object is \texttt{s} and how many entries does it have?

6. We see that the output is a list with one component. Redefine \texttt{s} to be the first entry of the list. What kind of object is \texttt{s} and how many entries does it have?

7. When inspecting the string we obtained above, we see a common problem: white space before and after the other characters. Trimming is a common first step in string processing. These extra spaces will eventually make splitting the strings hard so we start by removing them. We learned about the command \texttt{str\_trim} that removes spaces at the start or end of the strings. Use this function to trim \texttt{s}.

8. We want to extract the numbers from the strings stored in \texttt{s}. However, there are many non-numeric characters that will get in the way. We can remove these, but before doing this we want to preserve the string with the column header, which includes the month abbreviation.
Use the \texttt{str\_which} function to find the rows with a header. Save these results to \texttt{header\_index}. Hint: find the first string that matches the pattern \texttt{2015} using the \texttt{str\_which} function.

9. Now we are going to define two objects: \texttt{month} will store the month and \texttt{header} will store the column names. Identify which row contains the header of the table. Save the content of the row into an object called \texttt{header}, then use \texttt{str\_split} to help define the two objects we need. Hints: the separator here is one or more spaces. Also, consider using the \texttt{simplify} argument.

10. Notice that towards the end of the page you see a \emph{totals} row followed by rows with other summary statistics. Create an object called \texttt{tail\_index} with the index of the \emph{totals} entry.

11. Because our PDF page includes graphs with numbers, some of our rows have just one number (from the y-axis of the plot). Use the \texttt{str\_count} function to create an object \texttt{n} with the number of numbers in each each row. Hint: you can write a regex for number like this \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}d+}.

12. We are now ready to remove entries from rows that we know we don't need. The entry \texttt{header\_index} and everything before it should be removed. Entries for which \texttt{n} is 1 should also be removed, and the entry \texttt{tail\_index} and everything that comes after it should be removed as well.

13. Now we are ready to remove all the non-numeric entries. Do this using regex and the \texttt{str\_remove\_all} function. Hint: remember that in regex, using the upper case version of a special character usually means the opposite. So \texttt{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}D} means ``not a digit''. Remember you also want to keep spaces.

14. To convert the strings into a table, use the \texttt{str\_split\_fixed} function. Convert \texttt{s} into a data matrix with just the day and death count data. Hints: note that the separator is one or more spaces.
