\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/binsmoother-animation-1} \end{center}

The final code and resulting estimate look like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{span <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{7} 
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{with}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{, }
            \KeywordTok{ksmooth}\NormalTok{(day, margin, }\DataTypeTok{kernel =} \StringTok{"box"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{bandwidth =}\NormalTok{ span))}

\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008} \OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{smooth =}\NormalTok{ fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{size =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"grey"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, smooth), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"red"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/binsmoother-final-1} \end{center}

\hypertarget{kernels}{%
\section{Kernels}\label{kernels}}

The final result from the bin smoother is quite wiggly. One reason for this is that each time the window moves, two points change. We can attenuate this somewhat by taking weighted averages that give the center point more weight than far away points, with the two points at the edges receiving very little weight.

You can think of the bin smoother approach as a weighted average:

\[
\hat{f}(x_0) = \sum_{i=1}^N w_0(x_i) Y_i
\]

in which each point receives a weight of either \(0\) or \(1/N_0\), with \(N_0\) the number of points in the week. In the code above, we used the argument \texttt{kernel="box"} in our call to the function \texttt{ksmooth}. This is because the weight function looks like a box.
The \texttt{ksmooth} function provides a ``smoother'' option which uses the normal density to assign weights.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{-125}

\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{w_0 =} \DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{*}\KeywordTok{I}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{abs}\NormalTok{(x }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}\OperatorTok{<=}\NormalTok{span}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{w_0 =}\NormalTok{ w_}\DecValTok{0}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(w_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, w_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_step}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Box"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{with}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{day =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{min}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day), }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day), }\FloatTok{.25}\NormalTok{)), }
                       \KeywordTok{ksmooth}\NormalTok{(day, }\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{*}\KeywordTok{I}\NormalTok{(day }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{kernel =} \StringTok{"normal"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{x.points =}\NormalTok{ day, }\DataTypeTok{bandwidth =}\NormalTok{ span))}
\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x, }\DataTypeTok{w_0 =}\NormalTok{ tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{w_0 =}\NormalTok{ w_}\DecValTok{0}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(w_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, w_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Normal"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{gridExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p1, p2, }\DataTypeTok{ncol =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.8\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/gaussian-kernel-1} \end{center}

The final code and resulting plot for the normal kerenl look like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{span <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{7}
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{with}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{, }
            \KeywordTok{ksmooth}\NormalTok{(day, margin, }\DataTypeTok{kernel =} \StringTok{"normal"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{bandwidth =}\NormalTok{ span))}

\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008} \OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{smooth =}\NormalTok{ fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{size =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"grey"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, smooth), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"red"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/final-ksmooth-normal-kernel-1} \end{center}

Notice that the final estimate now looks smoother.

There are several functions in R that implement bin smoothers. One example is \texttt{ksmooth}, shown above. In practice, however, we typically prefer methods that use slightly more complex models than fitting a constant. The final result above, for example, is still somewhat wiggly in parts we don't expect it to be (between -125 and -75, for example). Methods such as \texttt{loess}, which we explain next, improve on this.

\hypertarget{local-weighted-regression-loess}{%
\section{Local weighted regression (loess)}\label{local-weighted-regression-loess}}

A limitation of the bin smoother approach just described is that we need small windows for the approximately constant assumptions to hold. As a result, we end up with a small number of data points to average and obtain imprecise estimates \(\hat{f}(x)\). Here we describe how \emph{local weighted regression} (loess) permits us to consider larger window sizes. To do this, we will use a mathematical result, referred to as Taylor's theorem, which tells us that if you look closely enough at any smooth function \(f(x)\), it will look like a line. To see why this makes sense, consider the curved edges gardeners make using straight-edged spades:

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{ml/img/garden} \end{center}

(``Downing Street garden path edge''\footnote{\url{https://www.flickr.com/photos/49707497@N06/7361631644}} by Flckr user Number 10\footnote{\url{https://www.flickr.com/photos/number10gov/}}. CC-BY 2.0 license\footnote{\url{https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/}}.)

Instead of assuming the function is approximately constant in a window, we assume the function is locally linear. We can consider larger window sizes with the linear assumption than with a constant. Instead of the one-week window, we consider a larger one in which the trend is approximately linear. We start with a three-week window and later consider and evaluate other options:

\[
E[Y_i | X_i = x_i ] = \beta_0 + \beta_1 (x_i-x_0) \mbox{   if   }  |x_i - x_0| \leq 21
\]

For every point \(x_0\), loess defines a window and fits a line within that window. Here is an example showing the fits for \(x_0=-125\) and \(x_0 = -55\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{span <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{21}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{diff}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{range}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day))}

\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008} \OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{crossing}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{center =}\NormalTok{ polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{dist =} \KeywordTok{abs}\NormalTok{(day }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{center)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rank}\NormalTok{(dist) }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{n}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{<=}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{span) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{weight =}\NormalTok{ (}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{(dist }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(dist)) }\OperatorTok{^}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{^}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(center }\OperatorTok{%in%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{125}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{-55}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{   }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_size}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{range =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_smooth}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{group =}\NormalTok{ center, }\DataTypeTok{weight =}\NormalTok{ weight), }
              \DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"lm"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{se =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{size =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"grey"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{size =}\NormalTok{ weight)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{facet_wrap}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{~}\NormalTok{center)}
\CommentTok{#> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/loess-1} \end{center}

The fitted value at \(x_0\) becomes our estimate \(\hat{f}(x_0)\). Below we show the procedure happening as we move from the -155 up to 0.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(broom)}
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{loess}\NormalTok{(margin }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{day, }\DataTypeTok{degree=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ span, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{loess_fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{augment}\NormalTok{(fit)}

\CommentTok{# if(!file.exists(file.path(img_path,"loess-animation.gif")))\{}
\CommentTok{#   p <- ggplot(tmp, aes(day, margin)) +}
\CommentTok{#     scale_size(range = c(0, 3)) +}
\CommentTok{#     geom_smooth(aes(group = center, frame = center, weight = weight), method = "lm", se = FALSE) +}
\CommentTok{#     geom_point(data = polls_2008, size = 3, alpha = .5, color = "grey") +}
\CommentTok{#     geom_point(aes(size = weight, frame = center)) +}
\CommentTok{#     geom_line(aes(x=day, y = .fitted, frame = day, cumulative = TRUE), }
\CommentTok{#               data = loess_fit, color = "red")}
\CommentTok{# }
\CommentTok{#   gganimate(p, filename = file.path(img_path,"loess-animation.gif"), interval= .1)}
\CommentTok{# \}}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{is_html_output}\NormalTok{())\{}
\NormalTok{  knitr}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{include_graphics}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{file.path}\NormalTok{(img_path,}\StringTok{"loess-animation.gif"}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{\} }\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{\{}
\NormalTok{  centers <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{quantile}\NormalTok{(tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{center, }\KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{,}\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{)}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  tmp_loess_fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{crossing}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{center=}\NormalTok{centers, loess_fit) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(center) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(day }\OperatorTok{<=}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{center) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{ungroup}\NormalTok{()}
        
\NormalTok{  tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(center }\OperatorTok{%in%}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{centers) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{geom_smooth}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin), }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"lm"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{se =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin, }\DataTypeTok{size =}\NormalTok{ weight), }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{size =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"grey"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x=}\NormalTok{day, }\DataTypeTok{y =}\NormalTok{ .fitted), }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ tmp_loess_fit, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"red"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{facet_wrap}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{~}\NormalTok{center, }\DataTypeTok{nrow =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\CommentTok{#> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/loess-animation-1} \end{center}

The final result is a smoother fit than the bin smoother since we use larger sample sizes to estimate our local parameters:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{total_days <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{diff}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{range}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day))}
\NormalTok{span <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{21}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{total_days}

\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{loess}\NormalTok{(margin }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{day, }\DataTypeTok{degree=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ span, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008} \OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{smooth =}\NormalTok{ fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{fitted) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{size =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"grey"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, smooth), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"red"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/final-loess-1} \end{center}

Different spans give us different estimates. We can see how different window sizes lead to different estimates:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{spans <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(.}\DecValTok{66}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.25}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.15}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.10}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{fits <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{tibble}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ spans) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(span) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{do}\NormalTok{(broom}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{augment}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{loess}\NormalTok{(margin }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{day, }\DataTypeTok{degree=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ .}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{span, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)))}

\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{fits }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{crossing}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{center =}\NormalTok{ polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{dist =} \KeywordTok{abs}\NormalTok{(day }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{center)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rank}\NormalTok{(dist) }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{n}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{<=}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{span) }\OperatorTok{%>%}

Here are the final estimates:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{spans <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(.}\DecValTok{66}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.25}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.15}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.10}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{fits <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{tibble}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ spans) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(span) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{do}\NormalTok{(broom}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{augment}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{loess}\NormalTok{(margin }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{day, }\DataTypeTok{degree=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ .}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{span, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)))}

\NormalTok{tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{size =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"grey"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, .fitted), }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ fits, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"red"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/loess-final-1} \end{center}

There are three other differences between \texttt{loess} and the typical bin smoother.

1. Rather than keeping the bin size the same, \texttt{loess} keeps the number of points used in the local fit the same. This number is controlled via the \texttt{span} argument, which expects a proportion. For example, if \texttt{N} is the number of data points and \texttt{span=0.5}, then for a given \(x\), \texttt{loess} will use the \texttt{0.5\ *\ N} closest points to \(x\) for the fit.

2. When fitting a line locally, \texttt{loess} uses a \emph{weighted} approach. Basically, instead of using least squares, we minimize a weighted version:

\[
\sum_{i=1}^N w_0(x_i) \left[Y_i - \left\{\beta_0 + \beta_1 (x_i-x_0)\right\}\right]^2
\]

However, instead of the Gaussian kernel, loess uses a function called the Tukey tri-weight:

\[
W(u)= \left( 1  - |u|^3\right)^3 \mbox{ if } |u| \leq 1 \mbox{ and } W(u) = 0 \mbox{ if } |u| > 1
\]

To define the weights, we denote \(2h\) as the window size and define:

\[
w_0(x_i) = W\left(\frac{x_i - x_0}{h}\right)
\]

This kernel differs from the Gaussian kernel in that more points get values closer to the max:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{-125}

\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{with}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{day =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{min}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day), }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day), }\FloatTok{.25}\NormalTok{)), }
                       \KeywordTok{ksmooth}\NormalTok{(day, }\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{*}\KeywordTok{I}\NormalTok{(day }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{kernel =} \StringTok{"normal"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{x.points =}\NormalTok{ day, }\DataTypeTok{bandwidth =} \DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x, }\DataTypeTok{w_0 =}\NormalTok{ tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{w_0 =}\NormalTok{ w_}\DecValTok{0}\OperatorTok{/}\KeywordTok{sum}\NormalTok{(w_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, w_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Normal"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{min}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day), }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day), }\DataTypeTok{length.out =} \DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{w_0 =}\NormalTok{ (}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{abs}\NormalTok{(x}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{21}\NormalTok{)}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{3}\OperatorTok{*}\KeywordTok{I}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{abs}\NormalTok{(x}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}\OperatorTok{<=}\DecValTok{21}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, w_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{()  }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Tri-weight"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{gridExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p1, p2, }\DataTypeTok{ncol =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.8\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/triweight-kernel-1} \end{center}

3. \texttt{loess} has the option of fitting the local model \emph{robustly}. An iterative algorithm is implemented in which, after fitting a model in one iteration, outliers are detected and down-weighted for the next iteration. To use this option, we use the argument \texttt{family="symmetric"}.

\hypertarget{fitting-parabolas}{%
\subsection{Fitting parabolas}\label{fitting-parabolas}}

Taylor's theorem also tells us that if you look at any mathematical function closely enough, it looks like a parabola. The theorem also states that you don't have to look as closely when approximating with parabolas as you do when approximating with lines. This means we can make our windows even larger and fit parabolas instead of lines.

\[
E[Y_i | X_i = x_i ] = \beta_0 + \beta_1 (x_i-x_0) + \beta_2 (x_i-x_0)^2 \mbox{   if   }  |x_i - x_0| \leq h
\]

This is actually the default procedure of the function \texttt{loess}. You may have noticed that when we showed the code for using loess, we set \texttt{degree\ =\ 1}. This tells loess to fit polynomials of degree 1, a fancy name for lines. If you read the help page for loess, you will see that the argument \texttt{degree} defaults to 2. By default, loess fits parabolas not lines. Here is a comparison of the fitting lines (red dashed) and fitting parabolas (orange solid):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{total_days <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{diff}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{range}\NormalTok{(polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{day))}
\NormalTok{span <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{28}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{total_days}
\NormalTok{fit_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{loess}\NormalTok{(margin }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{day, }\DataTypeTok{degree=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ span, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{fit_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{loess}\NormalTok{(margin }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{day, }\DataTypeTok{span =}\NormalTok{ span, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)}


\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008} \OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{smooth_1 =}\NormalTok{ fit_}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{fitted, }\DataTypeTok{smooth_2 =}\NormalTok{ fit_}\DecValTok{2}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{fitted) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{size =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{alpha =} \FloatTok{.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"grey"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, smooth_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"red"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{lty =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, smooth_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"orange"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{lty =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/polls-2008-parabola-line-loess-1} \end{center}

The \texttt{degree\ =\ 2} gives us more wiggly results. We actually prefer \texttt{degree\ =\ 1} as it is less prone to this kind of noise.

\hypertarget{beware-of-default-smoothing-parameters}{%
\subsection{Beware of default smoothing parameters}\label{beware-of-default-smoothing-parameters}}

\texttt{ggplot} uses loess in its \texttt{geom\_smooth} function:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008} \OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_smooth}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/ggplot-loess-default-1} \end{center}

But be careful with default parameters as they are rarely optimal.
However, you can conveniently change them:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{polls_}\DecValTok{2008} \OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(day, margin)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_smooth}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"loess"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{span =} \FloatTok{0.15}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{method.args =} \KeywordTok{list}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{degree=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/ggplot-loess-degree-1-1} \end{center}

\hypertarget{smoothing-ml-connection}{%
\section{Connecting smoothing to machine learning}\label{smoothing-ml-connection}}

To see how smoothing relates to machine learning with a concrete example, consider our \ref{two-or-seven} example. If we define the outcome \(Y = 1\) for digits that are seven and \(Y=0\) for digits that are 2, then we are interested in estimating the conditional probability:

\[
p(x_1, x_2) = \mbox{Pr}(Y=1 \mid X_1=x_1 , X_2 = x_2).
\]
with \(X_1\) and \(X_2\) the two predictors defined in Section \ref{two-or-seven}. In this example, the 0s and 1s we observe are ``noisy'' because for some regions the probabilities \(p(x_1, x_2)\) are not that close to 0 or 1. So we need to estimate \(p(x_1, x_2)\). Smoothing is an alternative to accomplishing this. In Section \ref{two-or-seven} we saw that linear regression was not flexible enough to capture the non-linear nature of \(p(x_1, x_2)\), thus smoothing approaches may provide an improvement. In the next chapter we describe a popular machine learning algorithm, k-nearest neighbors, which is based on bin smoothing.

\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-47}}

2. Plot the smooth estimates against day of the year, all on the same plot but with different colors.

3. Suppose we want to predict 2s and 7s in our \texttt{mnist\_27} dataset with just the second covariate. Can we do this? On first inspection it appears the data does not have much predictive power. In fact, if we fit a regular logistic regression, the coefficient for \texttt{x\_2} is not significant!

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(broom)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"mnist_27"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{glm}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{family =} \StringTok{"binomial"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ .) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{tidy}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Plotting a scatterplot here is not useful since \texttt{y} is binary:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, y, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Fit a loess line to the data above and plot the results. Notice that there is predictive power, except the conditional probability is not linear.

\hypertarget{cross-validation}{%
\chapter{Cross validation}\label{cross-validation}}

In this chapter we introduce cross validation, one of the most important ideas in machine learning. Here we focus on the conceptual and mathematical aspects. We will describe how to implement cross validation in practice with the \textbf{caret} package later, in Section \ref{caret-cv} in the next chapter. To motivate the concept, we will use the two predictor digits data presented in Section \ref{two-or-seven} and introduce, for the first time, an actual machine learning algorithm: k-nearest neighbors (kNN).

\hypertarget{knn-cv-intro}{%
\section{Motivation with k-nearest neighbors}\label{knn-cv-intro}}

Let's start by loading the data and showing a plot of the predictors with outcome represented with color.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"mnist_27"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ y)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/mnist-27-data-1} \end{center}

We will use these data to estimate the conditional probability function

\[
p(x_1, x_2) = \mbox{Pr}(Y=1 \mid X_1=x_1 , X_2 = x_2).
\]
as defined in Section \ref{smoothing-ml-connection}. With k-nearest neighbors (kNN) we estimate \(p(x_1, x_2)\) in a similar way to bin smoothing. However, as we will see, kNN is easier to adapt to multiple dimensions. First we define the distance between all observations based on the features. Then, for any point \((x_1,x_2)\) for which we want an estimate of \(p(x_1, x_2)\), we look for the \(k\) nearest points to \((x_1,x_2)\) and then take an average of the 0s and 1s associated with these points. We refer to the set of points used to compute the average as the \emph{neighborhood}. Due to the connection we described earlier between conditional expectations and conditional probabilities, this gives us a \(\hat{p}(x_1,x_2)\), just like the bin smoother gave us an estimate of a trend. As with bin smoothers, we can control the flexibility of our estimate, in this case through the \(k\) parameter: larger \(k\)s result in smoother estimates, while smaller \(k\)s result in more flexible and more wiggly estimates.

To implement the algorithm, we can use the \texttt{knn3} function from the \textbf{caret} package. Looking at the help file for this package, we see that we can call it in one of two ways. We will use the first in which we specify a \emph{formula} and a data frame. The data frame contains all the data to be used. The formula has the form \texttt{outcome\ \textasciitilde{}\ predictor\_1\ +\ predictor\_2\ +\ predictor\_3} and so on. Therefore, we would type \texttt{y\ \textasciitilde{}\ x\_1\ +\ x\_2}. If we are going to use all the predictors, we can use the \texttt{.} like this \texttt{y\ \textasciitilde{}\ .}. The final call looks like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(caret)}
\NormalTok{knn_fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{knn3}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

For this function, we also need to pick a parameter: the number of neighbors to include. Let's start with the default \(k=5\).

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{knn_fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{knn3}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{k =} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In this case, since our dataset is balanced and we care just as much about sensitivity as we do about specificity, we will use accuracy to quantify performance.

The \texttt{predict} function for \texttt{knn} produces a probability for each class. We keep the probability of being a 7 as the estimate \(\hat{p}(x_1, x_2)\)

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>    0.815}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In Section \ref{two-or-seven} we used linear regression to generate an estimate.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fit_lm <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ .)}
\NormalTok{p_hat_lm <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit_lm, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test)}
\NormalTok{y_hat_lm <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(p_hat_lm }\OperatorTok{>}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_lm, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>     0.75}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

And we see that kNN, with the default parameter, already beats regression. To see why this is the case, we will plot \(\hat{p}(x_1, x_2)\) and compare it to the true conditional probability \(p(x_1, x_2)\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{# We use this function to plot the estimated conditional probabilities}
\NormalTok{plot_cond_prob <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat=}\OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{)\{}
\NormalTok{  tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p}
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.null}\NormalTok{(p_hat))\{}
\NormalTok{    tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\DataTypeTok{p=}\NormalTok{p_hat)}
\NormalTok{  \}}
\NormalTok{  tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{z=}\NormalTok{p, }\DataTypeTok{fill=}\NormalTok{p)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_raster}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{),}\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"True conditional probability"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"kNN-5 estimate"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(gridExtra)}

\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p2, p1, }\DataTypeTok{nrow=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/knn-fit-1} \end{center}

We see that kNN better adapts to the non-linear shape of \(p(x_1, x_2)\). However, our estimate has some islands of blue in the red area, which intuitively does not make much sense. This is due to what we call \emph{over-training}. We describe over-training in detail below. Over-training is the reason that we have higher accuracy in the train set compared to the test set:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>    0.882}

\NormalTok{y_hat_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>    0.815}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{over-training}{%
\subsection{Over-training}\label{over-training}}

Over-training is at its worst when we set \(k=1\). With \(k=1\), the estimate for each \((x_1, x_2)\) in the training set is obtained with just the \(y\) corresponding to that point. In this case, if the \((x_1, x_2)\) are unique, we will obtain perfect accuracy in the training set because each point is used to predict itself. Remember that if the predictors are not unique and have different outcomes for at least one set of predictors, then it is impossible to predict perfectly.

Here we fit a kNN model with \(k=1\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{knn_fit_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{knn3}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{k =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{y_hat_knn_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_knn_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.995}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, the test set accuracy is actually worse than logistic regression:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat_knn_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_knn_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>    0.745}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can see the over-fitting problem in this figure.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{knn =} \KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ .)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color=}\NormalTok{ y),}
             \DataTypeTok{pch=}\DecValTok{21}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{z =}\NormalTok{ knn), }\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Train set"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{knn =} \KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ .)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color=}\NormalTok{ y), }
             \DataTypeTok{pch=}\DecValTok{21}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{z =}\NormalTok{ knn), }\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Test set"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p1, p2, }\DataTypeTok{nrow=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/knn-1-overfit-1} \end{center}

The black curves denote the decision rule boundaries.

The estimate \(\hat{p}(x_1, x_2)\) follows the training data too closely (left). You can see that in the training set, boundaries have been drawn to perfectly surround a single red point in a sea of blue. Because most points \((x_1, x_2)\) are unique, the prediction is either 1 or 0 and the prediction for that point is the associated label. However, once we introduce the training set (right), we see that many of these small islands now have the opposite color and we end up making several incorrect predictions.

\hypertarget{over-smoothing}{%
\subsection{Over-smoothing}\label{over-smoothing}}

Although not as badly as with the previous examples, we saw that with \(k=5\) we also over-trained. Hence, we should consider a larger \(k\). Let's try, as an example, a much larger number: \(k=401\).

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{knn_fit_}\DecValTok{401}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{knn3}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{k =} \DecValTok{401}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{y_hat_knn_}\DecValTok{401}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit_}\DecValTok{401}\NormalTok{, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_knn_}\DecValTok{401}\NormalTok{, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>     0.79}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This turns out to be similar to regression:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit_lm, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p)}
\NormalTok{p_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{scales}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{squish}\NormalTok{(p_hat, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(p_hat) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Regression"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(knn_fit_}\DecValTok{401}\NormalTok{, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"kNN-401"}\NormalTok{)}
  
\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p1, p2, }\DataTypeTok{nrow=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/mnist-27-glm-est-1} \end{center}

This size of \(k\) is so large that it does not permit enough flexibility. We call this \emph{over-smoothing}.

\hypertarget{picking-the-k-in-knn}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{Picking the \(k\) in kNN}{Picking the k in kNN}}\label{picking-the-k-in-knn}}

So how do we pick \(k\)? In principle we want to pick the \(k\) that maximizes accuracy, or minimizes the expected MSE as defined in \ref{loss-function}. The goal of cross validation is to estimate these quantities for any given algorithm and set of tuning parameters such as \(k\). To understand why we need a special method to do this let's repeat what we did above but for different values of \(k\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{ks <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{251}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We do this using \texttt{map\_df} function to repeat the above for each one.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(purrr)}
\NormalTok{accuracy <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{map_df}\NormalTok{(ks, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(k)\{}
\NormalTok{  fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{knn3}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{k =}\NormalTok{ k)}
  
\NormalTok{  y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  cm_train <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}
\NormalTok{  train_error <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{cm_train}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
  
\NormalTok{  y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"class"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  cm_test <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}
\NormalTok{  test_error <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{cm_test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
  
  \KeywordTok{tibble}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{train =}\NormalTok{ train_error, }\DataTypeTok{test =}\NormalTok{ test_error)}
\NormalTok{\})}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that we estimate accuracy by using both the training set and the test set. We can now plot the accuracy estimates for each value of \(k\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{accuracy }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{k =}\NormalTok{ ks) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{gather}\NormalTok{(set, accuracy, }\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{k) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{set =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(set, }\DataTypeTok{levels =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"train"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"test"}\NormalTok{))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(k, accuracy, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ set)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/accuracy-vs-k-knn-1} \end{center}

First, note that the estimate obtained on the training set is generally lower than the estimate obtained with the test set, with the difference larger for smaller values of \(k\). This is due to over-training. Also note that the accuracy versus \(k\) plot is quite jagged. We do not expect this because small changes in \(k\) should not affect the algorithm's performance too much. The jaggedness is explained by the fact that the accuracy is computed on a sample and therefore is a random variable. This demonstrates why we prefer to minimize the expected loss rather than the loss we observe with one dataset.

If we were to use these estimates to pick the \(k\) that maximizes accuracy, we would use the estimates built on the test data:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{ks[}\KeywordTok{which.max}\NormalTok{(accuracy}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test)]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 41}
\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(accuracy}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.86}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Another reason we need a better estimate of accuracy is that if we use the test set to pick this \(k\), we should not expect the accompanying accuracy estimate to extrapolate to the real world. This is because even here we broke a golden rule of machine learning: we selected the \(k\) using the test set. Cross validation also provides an estimate that takes this into account.

\hypertarget{mathematical-description-of-cross-validation}{%
\section{Mathematical description of cross validation}\label{mathematical-description-of-cross-validation}}

In Section \ref{loss-function}, we described that a common goal of machine learning is to find an algorithm that produces predictors \(\hat{Y}\) for an outcome \(Y\) that minimizes the MSE:

\[
\mbox{MSE} = \mbox{E}\left\{ \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N (\hat{Y}_i - Y_i)^2 \right\}
\]
When all we have at our disposal is one dataset, we can estimate the MSE with the observed MSE like this:

\[
\hat{\mbox{MSE}} = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N (\hat{y}_i - y_i)^2
\]
These two are often referred to as the \emph{true error} and \emph{apparent error}, respectively.

There are two important characteristics of the apparent error we should always keep in mind:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  Because our data is random, the apparent error is a random variable. For example, the dataset we have may be a random sample from a larger population. An algorithm may have a lower apparent error than another algorithm due to luck.
\item
  If we train an algorithm on the same dataset that we use to compute the apparent error, we might be overtraining. In general, when we do this, the apparent error will be an underestimate of the true error. We will see an extreme example of this with k-nearest neighbors.
\end{enumerate}

Cross validation is a technique that permits us to alleviate both these problems. To understand cross validation, it helps to think of the true error, a theoretical quantity, as the average of many apparent errors obtained by applying the algorithm to \(B\) new random samples of the data, none of them used to train the algorithm. As shown in a previous chapter, we think of the true error as:

\[
\frac{1}{B} \sum_{b=1}^B \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \left(\hat{y}_i^b - y_i^b\right)^2 
\]
with \(B\) a large number that can be thought of as practically infinite.
As already mentioned, this is a theoretical quantity because we only have available one set of outcomes: \(y_1, \dots, y_n\). Cross validation is based on the idea of imitating the theoretical setup above as best we can with the data we have. To do this, we have to generate a series of different random samples. There are several approaches we can use, but the general idea for all of them is to randomly generate smaller datasets that are not used for training, and instead used to estimate the true error.

\hypertarget{k-fold-cross-validation}{%
\section{K-fold cross validation}\label{k-fold-cross-validation}}

The first one we describe is \emph{K-fold cross validation}.
Generally speaking, a machine learning challenge starts with a dataset (blue in the image below). We need to build an algorithm using this dataset that will eventually be used in completely independent datasets (yellow).

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-1} \end{center}

But we don't get to see these independent datasets.

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-2} \end{center}

So to imitate this situation, we carve out a piece of our dataset and pretend it is an independent dataset: we divide the dataset into a \emph{training set} (blue) and a \emph{test set} (red). We will train our algorithm exclusively on the training set and use the test set only for evaluation purposes.

We usually try to select a small piece of the dataset so that we have as much data as possible to train. However, we also want the test set to be large so that we obtain a stable estimate of the loss without fitting an impractical number of models. Typical choices are to use 10\%-20\% of the data for testing.

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-3} \end{center}

Let's reiterate that it is indispensable that we not use the test set at all: not for filtering out rows, not for selecting features, nothing!

Now this presents a new problem because for most machine learning algorithms we need to select parameters, for example the number of neighbors \(k\) in k-nearest neighbors. Here, we will refer to the set of parameters as \(\lambda\). We need to optimize algorithm parameters without using our test set and we know that if we optimize and evaluate on the same dataset, we will overtrain. This is where cross validation is most useful.

For each set of algorithm parameters being considered, we want an estimate of the MSE and then we will choose the parameters with the smallest MSE. Cross validation provides this estimate.

First, before we start the cross validation procedure, it is important to fix all the algorithm parameters. Although we will train the algorithm on the set of training sets, the parameters \(\lambda\) will be the same across all training sets. We will use \(\hat{y}_i(\lambda)\) to denote the predictors obtained when we use parameters \(\lambda\).

So, if we are going to imitate this definition:

\[
\mbox{MSE}(\lambda) = \frac{1}{B} \sum_{b=1}^B \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \left(\hat{y}_i^b(\lambda) - y_i^b\right)^2 
\]

we want to consider datasets that can be thought of as an independent random sample and we want to do this several times. With K-fold cross validation, we do it \(K\) times. In the cartoons, we are showing an example that uses \(K=5\).

We will eventually end up with \(K\) samples, but let's start by describing how to construct the first: we simply pick \(M=N/K\) observations at random (we round if \(M\) is not a round number) and think of these as a random sample \(y_1^b, \dots, y_M^b\), with \(b=1\). We call this the validation set:

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-4} \end{center}

Now we can fit the model in the training set, then compute the apparent error on the independent set:

\[
\hat{\mbox{MSE}}_b(\lambda) = \frac{1}{M}\sum_{i=1}^M \left(\hat{y}_i^b(\lambda) - y_i^b\right)^2 
\]

Note that this is just one sample and will therefore return a noisy estimate of the true error. This is why we take \(K\) samples, not just one. In K-cross validation, we randomly split the observations into \(K\) non-overlapping sets:

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-5} \end{center}

Now we repeat the calculation above for each of these sets \(b=1,\dots,K\) and obtain \(\hat{\mbox{MSE}}_1(\lambda),\dots, \hat{\mbox{MSE}}_K(\lambda)\). Then, for our final estimate, we compute the average:

\[
\hat{\mbox{MSE}}(\lambda) = \frac{1}{B} \sum_{b=1}^K \hat{\mbox{MSE}}_b(\lambda)
\]

and obtain an estimate of our loss. A final step would be to select the \(\lambda\) that minimizes the MSE.

We have described how to use cross validation to optimize parameters. However, we now have to take into account the fact that the optimization occurred on the training data and therefore we need an estimate of our final algorithm based on data that was not used to optimize the choice. Here is where we use the test set we separated early on:

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-6} \end{center}

We can do cross validation again:

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-7} \end{center}

and obtain a final estimate of our expected loss. However, note that this means that our entire compute time gets multiplied by \(K\). You will soon learn that performing this task takes time because we are performing many complex computations. As a result, we are always looking for ways to reduce this time. For the final evaluation, we often just use the one test set.

Once we are satisfied with this model and want to make it available to others, we could refit the model on the entire dataset, without changing the optimized parameters.

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.35\linewidth]{ml/img/cv-8} \end{center}

Now how do we pick the cross validation \(K\)? Large values of \(K\) are preferable because the training data better imitates the original dataset. However, larger values of \(K\) will have much slower computation time: for example, 100-fold cross validation will be 10 times slower than 10-fold cross validation. For this reason, the choices of \(K=5\) and \(K=10\) are popular.

One way we can improve the variance of our final estimate is to take more samples. To do this, we would no longer require the training set to be partitioned into non-overlapping sets. Instead, we would just pick \(K\) sets of some size at random.

One popular version of this technique, at each fold, picks observations at random with replacement (which means the same observation can appear twice). This approach has some advantages (not discussed here) and is generally referred to as the \emph{bootstrap}. In fact, this is the default approach in the \textbf{caret} package. We describe how to implement cross validation with the \textbf{caret} package in the next chapter. In the next section, we include an explanation of how the bootstrap works in general.

\hypertarget{exercises-48}{%
\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-48}}

Generate a set of random predictors and outcomes like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1996}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{n <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1000}
\NormalTok{p <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10000}
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(n }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{p), n, p)}
\KeywordTok{colnames}\NormalTok{(x) <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{paste}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"x"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\KeywordTok{ncol}\NormalTok{(x), }\DataTypeTok{sep =} \StringTok{"_"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rbinom}\NormalTok{(n, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{()}

\NormalTok{x_subset <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x[ ,}\KeywordTok{sample}\NormalTok{(p, }\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{)]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

1. Because \texttt{x} and \texttt{y} are completely independent, you should not be able to predict \texttt{y} using \texttt{x} with accuracy larger than 0.5. Confirm this by running cross validation using logistic regression to fit the model. Because we have so many predictors, we selected a random sample \texttt{x\_subset}. Use the subset when training the model. Hint: use the caret \texttt{train} function. The \texttt{results} component of the output of \texttt{train} shows you the accuracy. Ignore the warnings.

2. Now, instead of a random selection of predictors, we are going to search for those that are most predictive of the outcome. We can do this by comparing the values for the \(y=1\) group to those in the \(y=0\) group, for each predictor, using a t-test. You can perform this step like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{devtools}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{install_bioc}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"genefilter"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{install.packages}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"genefilter"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(genefilter)}
\NormalTok{tt <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{colttests}\NormalTok{(x, y)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Create a vector of the p-values and call it \texttt{pvals}.

3. Create an index \texttt{ind} with the column numbers of the predictors that were ``statistically significantly'' associated with \texttt{y}. Use a p-value cutoff of 0.01 to define ``statistically significant''. How many predictors survive this cutoff?

4. Re-run the cross validation but after redefining \texttt{x\_subset} to be the subset of \texttt{x} defined by the columns showing ``statistically significant'' association with \texttt{y}. What is the accuracy now?

5. Re-run the cross validation again, but this time using kNN. Try out the following grid of tuning parameters: \texttt{k\ =\ seq(101,\ 301,\ 25)}. Make a plot of the resulting accuracy.

6. In exercises 3 and 4, we see that despite the fact that \texttt{x} and \texttt{y} are completely independent, we were able to predict \texttt{y} with accuracy higher than 70\%. We must be doing something wrong then. What is it?

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\alph{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  The function \texttt{train} estimates accuracy on the same data it uses to train the algorithm.
\item
  We are over-fitting the model by including 100 predictors.
\item
  We used the entire dataset to select the columns used in the model. This step needs to be included as part of the algorithm. The cross validation was done \textbf{after} this selection.
\item
  The high accuracy is just due to random variability.
\end{enumerate}

7. Advanced. Re-do the cross validation but this time include the selection step in the cross validation. The accuracy should now be close to 50\%.

8. Load the \texttt{tissue\_gene\_expression} dataset. Use the \texttt{train} function to predict tissue from gene expression. Use kNN. What \texttt{k} works best?

\hypertarget{bootstrap}{%
\section{Bootstrap}\label{bootstrap}}

Suppose the income distribution of your population is as follows:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1995}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{n <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{6}
\NormalTok{income <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\OperatorTok{^}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(n, }\KeywordTok{log10}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{45000}\NormalTok{), }\KeywordTok{log10}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)))}
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{log10}\NormalTok{(income), }\DataTypeTok{bins =} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \KeywordTok{I}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/income-distribution-1} \end{center}

The population median is:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{m <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{median}\NormalTok{(income)}
\NormalTok{m}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 44939}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Suppose we don't have access to the entire population, but want to estimate the median \(m\). We take a sample of 100 and estimate the population median \(m\) with the sample median \(M\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{N <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{100}
\NormalTok{X <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{sample}\NormalTok{(income, N)}
\KeywordTok{median}\NormalTok{(X)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 38461}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Can we construct a confidence interval? What is the distribution of \(M\) ?

Because we are simulating the data, we can use a Monte Carlo simulation to learn the distribution of \(M\).

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(gridExtra)}
\NormalTok{B <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{4}
\NormalTok{M <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{replicate}\NormalTok{(B, \{}
\NormalTok{  X <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{sample}\NormalTok{(income, N)}
  \KeywordTok{median}\NormalTok{(X)}
\NormalTok{\})}
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(M, }\DataTypeTok{bins =} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \KeywordTok{I}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{sample =} \KeywordTok{scale}\NormalTok{(M), }\DataTypeTok{xlab =} \StringTok{"theoretical"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{ylab =} \StringTok{"sample"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_abline}\NormalTok{()}
\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p1, p2, }\DataTypeTok{ncol =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/median-is-normal-1} \end{center}

If we know this distribution, we can construct a confidence interval. The problem here is that, as we have already described, in practice we do not have access to the distribution. In the past, we have used the Central Limit Theorem, but the CLT we studied applies to averages and here we are interested in the median. We can see that the 95\% confidence interval based on CLT

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{median}\NormalTok{(X) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{1.96} \OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{sd}\NormalTok{(X) }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{sqrt}\NormalTok{(N) }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 21018 55905}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

is quite different from the confidence interval we would generate if we know the actual distribution of \(M\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{quantile}\NormalTok{(M, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.025}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.975}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#>  2.5% 97.5% }
\CommentTok{#> 34438 59050}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The bootstrap permits us to approximate a Monte Carlo simulation without access to the entire distribution. The general idea is relatively simple. We act as if the observed sample is the population. We then sample (with replacement) datasets, of the same sample size as the original dataset. Then we compute the summary statistic, in this case the median, on these \emph{bootstrap samples}.

Theory tells us that, in many situations, the distribution of the statistics obtained with bootstrap samples approximate the distribution of our actual statistic. This is how we construct bootstrap samples and an approximate distribution:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{B <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{4}
\NormalTok{M_star <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{replicate}\NormalTok{(B, \{}
\NormalTok{  X_star <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{sample}\NormalTok{(X, N, }\DataTypeTok{replace =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
  \KeywordTok{median}\NormalTok{(X_star)}
\NormalTok{\})}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note a confidence interval constructed with the bootstrap is much closer to one constructed with the theoretical distribution:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{quantile}\NormalTok{(M_star, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.025}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.975}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#>  2.5% 97.5% }
\CommentTok{#> 30253 56909}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

For more on the Bootstrap, including corrections one can apply to improve these confidence intervals, please consult the book \emph{An introduction to the bootstrap} by Efron, B., \& Tibshirani, R. J.

\emph{Note that we can use ideas similar to those used in the bootstrap in cross validation: instead of dividing the data into equal partitions, we simply bootstrap many times.}

\hypertarget{exercises-49}{%
\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-49}}

1. The \texttt{createResample} function can be used to create bootstrap samples. For example, we can create 10 bootstrap samples for the \texttt{mnist\_27} dataset like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1995}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{indexes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{createResample}\NormalTok{(mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y, }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

How many times do \texttt{3}, \texttt{4}, and \texttt{7} appear in the first re-sampled index?

2. We see that some numbers appear more than once and others appear no times. This has to be this way for each dataset to be independent. Repeat the exercise for all the re-sampled indexes.

3. Generate a random dataset like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Estimate the 75th quantile, which we know is:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{qnorm}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

with the sample quantile:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{quantile}\NormalTok{(y, }\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Run a Monte Carlo simulation to learn the expected value and standard error of this random variable.

4. In practice, we can't run a Monte Carlo simulation because we don't know if \texttt{rnorm} is being used to simulate the data. Use the bootstrap to estimate the standard error using just the initial sample \texttt{y}. Use 10 bootstrap samples.

5. Redo exercise 4, but with 10,000 bootstrap samples.

\hypertarget{caret}{%
\chapter{The caret package}\label{caret}}

We have already learned about regression and kNN as machine learning algorithms. In later sections, we learn several others, and this is just a small subset of all the algorithms out there. Many of these algorithms are implemented in R. However, they are distributed via different packages, developed by different authors, and often use different syntax. The \textbf{caret} package tries to consolidate these differences and provide consistency. It currently includes 237 different methods which are summarized in the \textbf{caret} package manual\footnote{\url{https://topepo.github.io/caret/available-models.html}}. Keep in mind that \textbf{caret} does not include the needed packages and, to implement a package through \textbf{caret}, you still need to install the library. The required packages for each method are described in the package manual.

The \textbf{caret} package also provides a function that performs cross validation for us. Here we provide some examples showing how we use this incredibly helpful package. We will use the 2 or 7 example to illustrate:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"mnist_27"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-caret-train-functon}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{The caret \texttt{train} functon}{The caret train functon}}\label{the-caret-train-functon}}

The \textbf{caret} \texttt{train} function lets us train different algorithms using similar syntax. So, for example, we can type:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(caret)}
\NormalTok{train_glm <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"glm"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\NormalTok{train_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"knn"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To make predictions, we can use the output of this function directly without needing to look at the specifics of \texttt{predict.glm} and \texttt{predict.knn}. Instead, we can learn how to obtain predictions from \texttt{predict.train}.

The code looks the same for both methods:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat_glm <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_glm, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"raw"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{y_hat_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"raw"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This permits us to quickly compare the algorithms. For example, we can compare the accuracy like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_glm, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.75}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]]}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.84}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{caret-cv}{%
\section{Cross validation}\label{caret-cv}}

When an algorithm includes a tuning parameter, \texttt{train} automatically uses cross validation to decide among a few default values. To find out what parameter or parameters are optimized, you can read the manual \footnote{\url{http://topepo.github.io/caret/available-models.html}} or study the output of:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{getModelInfo}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"knn"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can also use a quick lookup like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{modelLookup}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"knn"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If we run it with default values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"knn"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

you can quickly see the results of the cross validation using the \texttt{ggplot} function. The argument \texttt{highlight} highlights the max:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(train_knn, }\DataTypeTok{highlight =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/caret-highlight-1} \end{center}

By default, the cross validation is performed by taking 25 bootstrap samples comprised of 25\% of the observations. For the \texttt{kNN} method, the default is to try \(k=5,7,9\).
