We change this using the \texttt{tuneGrid} parameter. The grid of values must be supplied by a data frame with the parameter names as specified in the \texttt{modelLookup} output.

Here, we present an example where we try out 30 values between 9 and 67. To do this with \textbf{caret}, we need to define a column named \texttt{k}, so we use this:
\texttt{data.frame(k\ =\ seq(9,\ 67,\ 2))}.

Note that when running this code, we are fitting 30 versions of kNN to 25 bootstrapped samples. Since we are fitting \(30 \times 25 = 750\) kNN models, running this code will take several seconds. We set the seed because cross validation is a random procedure and we want to make sure the result here is reproducible.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{train_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"knn"}\NormalTok{, }
                   \DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train,}
                   \DataTypeTok{tuneGrid =} \KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{k =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{71}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)))}
\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(train_knn, }\DataTypeTok{highlight =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/train-knn-plot-1} \end{center}

To access the parameter that maximized the accuracy, you can use this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_knn}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{bestTune}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

and the best performing model like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_knn}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{finalModel}
\CommentTok{#> 27-nearest neighbor model}
\CommentTok{#> Training set outcome distribution:}
\CommentTok{#> }
\CommentTok{#>   2   7 }
\CommentTok{#> 379 421}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The function \texttt{predict} will use this best performing model. Here is the accuracy of the best model when applied to the test set, which we have not used at all yet because the cross validation was done on the training set:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"raw"}\NormalTok{),}
\NormalTok{                mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>    0.835}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If we want to change how we perform cross validation, we can use the \texttt{trainControl} function. We can make the code above go a bit faster by using, for example, 10-fold cross validation. This means we have 10 samples using 10\% of the observations each. We accomplish this using the following code:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{control <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{trainControl}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"cv"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{number =} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{p =} \FloatTok{.9}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{train_knn_cv <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"knn"}\NormalTok{, }
                   \DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train,}
                   \DataTypeTok{tuneGrid =} \KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{k =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{71}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)),}
                   \DataTypeTok{trControl =}\NormalTok{ control)}
\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(train_knn_cv, }\DataTypeTok{highlight =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/cv-10-fold-accuracy-estimate-1} \end{center}

We notice that the accuracy estimates are more variable, which is expected since we changed the number of samples used to estimate accuracy.

Note that \texttt{results} component of the \texttt{train} output includes several summary statistics related to the variability of the cross validation estimates:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{names}\NormalTok{(train_knn}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{results)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] "k"          "Accuracy"   "Kappa"      "AccuracySD" "KappaSD"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{example-fitting-with-loess}{%
\section{Example: fitting with loess}\label{example-fitting-with-loess}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{plot_cond_prob <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat=}\OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{)\{}
\NormalTok{  tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p}
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.null}\NormalTok{(p_hat))\{}
\NormalTok{    tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\DataTypeTok{p=}\NormalTok{p_hat)}
\NormalTok{  \}}
\NormalTok{  tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{z=}\NormalTok{p, }\DataTypeTok{fill=}\NormalTok{p)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_raster}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{),}\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The best fitting kNN model approximates the true conditional probability:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"prob"}\NormalTok{)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{])}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/mnist27-optimal-knn-fit-1} \end{center}

However, we do see that the boundary is somewhat wiggly. This is because kNN, like the basic bin smoother, does not use a kernel. To improve this we could try loess. By reading through the available models part of the manual\footnote{\url{https://topepo.github.io/caret/available-models.html}} we see that we can use the \texttt{gamLoess} method.
In the manual\footnote{\url{https://topepo.github.io/caret/train-models-by-tag.html}} we also see that we need to install the \textbf{gam} package if we have not done so already:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{install.packages}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"gam"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Then we see that we have two parameters to optimize:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{modelLookup}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"gamLoess"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We will stick to a degree of 1. But to try out different values for the span, we still have to include a column in the table with the name \texttt{degree} so we can do this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{grid <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{expand.grid}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{span =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.15}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.65}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{len =} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{degree =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We will use the default cross validation control parameters.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_loess <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }
                   \DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"gamLoess"}\NormalTok{, }
                   \DataTypeTok{tuneGrid=}\NormalTok{grid,}
                   \DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\CommentTok{#> 1 package is needed for this model and is not installed. (gam). Would you like to try to install it now?}
\CommentTok{#> 1: yes}
\CommentTok{#> 2: no}
\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(train_loess, }\DataTypeTok{highlight =} \OtherTok{TRUE}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/loess-accuracy-1} \end{center}

We can see that the method performs similar to kNN:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =} \KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_loess, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test), }
                \DataTypeTok{reference =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>     0.85}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

and produces a smoother estimate of the conditional probability:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"True conditional probability"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_loess, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"prob"}\NormalTok{)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"GAM Loess estimate"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{gridExtra}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p2, p1, }\DataTypeTok{nrow=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/gam-smooth-1} \end{center}

\hypertarget{examples-of-algorithms}{%
\chapter{Examples of algorithms}\label{examples-of-algorithms}}

There are dozens of machine learning algorithms. Here we provide a few examples spanning rather different approaches. Throughout the chapter we will be using the two predictor digits data introduced in Section \ref{two-or-seven} to demonstrate how the algorithms work.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(caret)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"mnist_27"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{linear-regression}{%
\section{Linear regression}\label{linear-regression}}

Linear regression can be considered a machine learning algorithm. In Section \ref{two-or-seven} we demonstrated how linear regression can be too rigid to be useful. This is generally true, but for some challenges it works rather well. It also serves as a baseline approach: if you can't beat it with a more complex approach, you probably want to stick to linear regression. To quickly make the connection between regression and machine learning, we will reformulate Galton's study with heights, a continuous outcome.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(HistData)}

\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1983}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{galton_heights <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{GaltonFamilies }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(gender }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "male"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(family) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{sample_n}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ungroup}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{select}\NormalTok{(father, childHeight) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{rename}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{son =}\NormalTok{ childHeight)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Suppose you are tasked with building a machine learning algorithm that predicts the son's height \(Y\) using the father's height \(X\). Let's generate testing and training sets:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{galton_heights}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{son}
\NormalTok{test_index <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{createDataPartition}\NormalTok{(y, }\DataTypeTok{times =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{p =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{list =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{train_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{galton_heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{test_index)}
\NormalTok{test_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{galton_heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(test_index)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In this case, if we were just ignoring the father's height and guessing the son's height, we would guess the average height of sons.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{m <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(train_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{son)}
\NormalTok{m}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 69.2}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Our squared loss is:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{((m }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{son)}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 7.65}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Can we do better? In the regression chapter, we learned that if the pair \((X,Y)\) follow a bivariate normal distribution, the conditional expectation (what we want to estimate) is equivalent to the regression line:

\[
f(x) = \mbox{E}( Y  \mid  X= x ) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x
\]

In Section \ref{lse} we introduced least squares as a method for estimating the slope \(\beta_0\) and intercept \(\beta_1\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(son }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{father, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ train_set)}
\NormalTok{fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef}
\CommentTok{#> (Intercept)      father }
\CommentTok{#>      35.976       0.482}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This gives us an estimate of the conditional expectation:

\[ \hat{f}(x) = 52 + 0.25 x \]

We can see that this does indeed provide an improvement over our guessing approach.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{father}
\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{((y_hat }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{son)}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 6.47}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-predict-function}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{The \texttt{predict} function}{The predict function}}\label{the-predict-function}}

The \texttt{predict} function is very useful for machine learning applications. This function takes a fitted object from functions such as \texttt{lm} or \texttt{glm} (we learn about \texttt{glm} soon) and a data frame with the new predictors for which to predict. So in our current example, we would use \texttt{predict} like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit, test_set)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Using \texttt{predict}, we can get the same results as we did previously:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit, test_set)}
\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{((y_hat }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{son)}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 6.47}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\texttt{predict} does not always return objects of the same types; it depends on what type of object is sent to it. To learn about the specifics, you need to look at the help file specific for the type of fit object that is being used. The \texttt{predict} is actually a special type of function in R (called a \emph{generic function}) that calls other functions depending on what kind of object it receives. So if \texttt{predict} receives an object coming out of the \texttt{lm} function, it will call \texttt{predict.lm}. If it receives an object coming out of \texttt{glm}, it calls \texttt{predict.glm}. These two functions are similar but different. You can learn more about the differences by reading the help files:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{?predict.lm}
\NormalTok{?predict.glm}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

There are many other versions of \texttt{predict} and many machine learning algorithms have a \texttt{predict} function.

\hypertarget{exercises-50}{%
\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-50}}

1. Create a dataset using the following code.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{n <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{100}
\NormalTok{Sigma <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{9}\OperatorTok{*}\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{1.0}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{1.0}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{MASS}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{mvrnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{n =} \DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{69}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{69}\NormalTok{), Sigma) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"x"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"y"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Use the \textbf{caret} package to partition into a test and training set of equal size. Train a linear model and report the RMSE. Repeat this exercise 100 times and make a histogram of the RMSEs and report the average and standard deviation. Hint: adapt the code shown earlier like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{dat}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y}
\NormalTok{test_index <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{createDataPartition}\NormalTok{(y, }\DataTypeTok{times =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{p =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{list =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{train_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{dat }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{test_index)}
\NormalTok{test_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{dat }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(test_index)}
\NormalTok{fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ train_set)}
\NormalTok{y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x}
\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{((y_hat }\OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

and put it inside a call to \texttt{replicate}.

2. Now we will repeat the above but using larger datasets. Repeat exercise 1 but for datasets with \texttt{n\ \textless{}-\ c(100,\ 500,\ 1000,\ 5000,\ 10000)}. Save the average and standard deviation of RMSE from the 100 repetitions. Hint: use the \texttt{sapply} or \texttt{map} functions.

3. Describe what you observe with the RMSE as the size of the dataset becomes larger.

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\alph{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  On average, the RMSE does not change much as \texttt{n} gets larger, while the variability of RMSE does decrease.
\item
  Because of the law of large numbers, the RMSE decreases: more data, more precise estimates.
\item
  \texttt{n\ =\ 10000} is not sufficiently large. To see a decrease in RMSE, we need to make it larger.
\item
  The RMSE is not a random variable.
\end{enumerate}

4. Now repeat exercise 1, but this time make the correlation between \texttt{x} and \texttt{y} larger by changing \texttt{Sigma} like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{n <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{100}
\NormalTok{Sigma <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{9}\OperatorTok{*}\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.95}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.95}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{MASS}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{mvrnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{n =} \DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{69}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{69}\NormalTok{), Sigma) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"x"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"y"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Repeat the exercise and note what happens to the RMSE now.

5. Which of the following best explains why the RMSE in exercise 4 is so much lower than exercise 1.

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\alph{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  It is just luck. If we do it again, it will be larger.
\item
  The Central Limit Theorem tells us the RMSE is normal.
\item
  When we increase the correlation between \texttt{x} and \texttt{y}, \texttt{x} has more predictive power and thus provides a better estimate of \texttt{y}. This correlation has a much bigger effect on RMSE than \texttt{n}. Large \texttt{n} simply provide us more precise estimates of the linear model coefficients.
\item
  These are both examples of regression, so the RMSE has to be the same.
\end{enumerate}

6. Create a dataset using the following code:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{n <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1000}
\NormalTok{Sigma <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\OperatorTok{/}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{MASS}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{mvrnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{n =} \DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{), Sigma) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"y"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"x_1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"x_2"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that \texttt{y} is correlated with both \texttt{x\_1} and \texttt{x\_2}, but the two predictors are independent of each other.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(dat)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Use the \textbf{caret} package to partition into a test and training set of equal size. Compare the RMSE when using just \texttt{x\_1}, just \texttt{x\_2}, and both \texttt{x\_1} and \texttt{x\_2}. Train a linear model and report the RMSE.

7. Repeat exercise 6 but now create an example in which \texttt{x\_1} and \texttt{x\_2} are highly correlated:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{n <-}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1000}
\NormalTok{Sigma <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{1.0}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{1.0}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.95}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.95}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{1.0}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{MASS}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{mvrnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{n =} \DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{, }\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{), Sigma) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"y"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"x_1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"x_2"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Use the \textbf{caret} package to partition into a test and training set of equal size. Compare the RMSE when using just \texttt{x\_1}, just \texttt{x\_2}, and both \texttt{x\_1} and \texttt{x\_2} Train a linear model and report the RMSE.

8. Compare the results in 6 and 7 and choose the statement you agree with:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\alph{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Adding extra predictors can improve RMSE substantially, but not when they are highly correlated with another predictor.
\item
  Adding extra predictors improves predictions equally in both exercises.
\item
  Adding extra predictors results in over fitting.
\item
  Unless we include all predictors, we have no predicting power.
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{logistic-regression}{%
\section{Logistic regression}\label{logistic-regression}}

The regression approach can be extended to categorical data. In this section we first illustrate how, for binary data, one can simply assign numeric values of 0 and 1 to the outcomes \(y\), and apply regression as if the data were continuous. We will then point out a limitation with this approach and introduce \emph{logistic regression} as a solution. Logistic regression is a specific case of a set of \emph{generalized linear models}. To illustrate logistic regression, we will apply it to our previous predicting sex example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"heights"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{height}
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{test_index <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{createDataPartition}\NormalTok{(y, }\DataTypeTok{times =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{p =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{list =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{train_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{test_index)}
\NormalTok{test_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(test_index)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If we define the outcome \(Y\) as 1 for females and 0 for males, and \(X\) as the height, we are interested in the conditional probability:

\[
\mbox{Pr}( Y = 1 \mid X = x)
\]

As an example, let's provide a prediction for a student that is 66 inches tall. What is the conditional probability of being female if you are 66 inches tall? In our dataset, we can estimate this by rounding to the nearest inch and computing:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_set }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(height)}\OperatorTok{==}\DecValTok{66}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{y_hat =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(sex}\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{"Female"}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To construct a prediction algorithm, we want to estimate the proportion of the population that is female for any given height \(X=x\), which we write as the conditional probability described above: \(\mbox{Pr}( Y = 1 | X=x)\). Let's see what this looks like for several values of \(x\) (we will remove strata of \(x\) with few data points):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(height)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(x) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{n}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{prop =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(sex }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Female"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, prop)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{()}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/height-and-sex-conditional-probabilities-1} \end{center}

Since the results from the plot above look close to linear, and it is the only approach we currently know, we will try regression. We assume that:

\[p(x) = \mbox{Pr}( Y = 1 | X=x)  = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x\]

Note: because \(p_0(x) = 1 - p_1(x)\), we will only estimate \(p_1(x)\) and drop the \(_1\) index.

If we convert the factors to 0s and 1s, we can estimate \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) with least squares.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{lm_fit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(train_set, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{as.numeric}\NormalTok{(sex }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Female"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{lm}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{height, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ .)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Once we have estimates \(\hat{\beta}_0\) and \(\hat{\beta}_1\), we can obtain an actual prediction. Our estimate of the conditional probability \(p(x)\) is:

\[
\hat{p}(x) = \hat{\beta}_0+ \hat{\beta}_1 x
\]

To form a prediction, we define a \emph{decision rule}: predict female if \(\hat{p}(x) > 0.5\). We can compare our predictions to the outcomes using:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(lm_fit, test_set)}
\NormalTok{y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(p_hat }\OperatorTok{>}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Female"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Male"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{()}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat, test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sex)[[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]]}
\CommentTok{#> NULL}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We see this method does substantially better than guessing.

\hypertarget{generalized-linear-models}{%
\subsection{Generalized linear models}\label{generalized-linear-models}}

The function \(\beta_0 + \beta_1 x\) can take any value including negatives and values larger than 1. In fact, the estimate \(\hat{p}(x)\) computed in the linear regression section does indeed become negative at around 76 inches.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(height)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(x) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{n}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{prop =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(sex }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Female"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, prop)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_abline}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{intercept =}\NormalTok{ lm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{], }\DataTypeTok{slope =}\NormalTok{ lm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{])}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/regression-prediction-1} \end{center}

The range is:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{range}\NormalTok{(p_hat)}
\CommentTok{#> [1] -0.331  1.036}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

But we are estimating a probability: \(\mbox{Pr}( Y = 1 \mid X = x)\) which is constrained between 0 and 1.

The idea of generalized linear models (GLM) is to 1) define a distribution of \(Y\) that is consistent with it's possible outcomes and
2) find a function \(g\) so that \(g(\mbox{Pr}( Y = 1 \mid X = x))\) can be modeled as a linear combination of predictors.
Logistic regression is the most commonly used GLM. It is an extension of linear regression that assures that the estimate of \(\mbox{Pr}( Y = 1 \mid X = x)\) is between 0 and 1. This approach makes use of the \emph{logistic} transformation introduced in Section \ref{logit}:

\[ g(p) = \log \frac{p}{1-p}\]

This logistic transformation converts probability to log odds. As discussed in the data visualization lecture, the odds tell us how much more likely it is something will happen compared to not happening. \(p=0.5\) means the odds are 1 to 1, thus the odds are 1. If \(p=0.75\), the odds are 3 to 1. A nice characteristic of this transformation is that it converts probabilities to be symmetric around 0. Here is a plot of \(g(p)\) versus \(p\):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.01}\NormalTok{,.}\DecValTok{99}\NormalTok{,}\DataTypeTok{len=}\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(p, }\KeywordTok{log}\NormalTok{( p}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{p) ), }\DataTypeTok{geom=}\StringTok{"line"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/p-versus-logistic-of-p-1} \end{center}

With \emph{logistic regression}, we model the conditional probability directly with:

\[ 
g\left\{ \mbox{Pr}(Y = 1 \mid X=x) \right\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x
\]

With this model, we can no longer use least squares. Instead we compute the \emph{maximum likelihood estimate} (MLE). You can learn more about this concept in a statistical theory textbook\footnote{\url{http://www.amazon.com/Mathematical-Statistics-Analysis-Available-Enhanced/dp/0534399428}}.

In R, we can fit the logistic regression model with the function \texttt{glm}: generalized linear models. This function is more general than logistic regression so we need to specify the model we want through the \texttt{family} parameter:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{glm_fit <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{train_set }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{as.numeric}\NormalTok{(sex }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Female"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{glm}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{height, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{family =} \StringTok{"binomial"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We can obtain prediction using the predict function:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p_hat_logit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(glm_fit, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ test_set, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"response"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When using \texttt{predict} with a \texttt{glm} object, we have to specify that we want \texttt{type="response"} if we want the conditional probabilities, since the default is to return the logistic transformed values.

This model fits the data slightly better than the line:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(height)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(x) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{n}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{prop =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(sex }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Female"}\NormalTok{)) }
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\NormalTok{logistic_curve <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{min}\NormalTok{(tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x), }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat =} \KeywordTok{plogis}\NormalTok{(glm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{glm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{x))}
\NormalTok{tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, prop)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ logistic_curve,}
             \DataTypeTok{mapping =} \KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, p_hat), }\DataTypeTok{lty =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/conditional-prob-glm-fit-1} \end{center}

Because we have an estimate \(\hat{p}(x)\), we can obtain predictions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat_logit <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(p_hat_logit }\OperatorTok{>}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Female"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Male"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{factor}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_logit, test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sex)[[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]]}
\CommentTok{#> NULL}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The resulting predictions are similar. This is because the two estimates of \(p(x)\) are larger than 1/2 in about the same region of x:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{min}\NormalTok{(tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x), }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{logistic =} \KeywordTok{plogis}\NormalTok{(glm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{glm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{x),}
         \DataTypeTok{regression =}\NormalTok{ lm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{lm_fit}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{coef[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{x) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{gather}\NormalTok{(method, p_x, }\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{x) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, p_x, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ method)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_hline}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{yintercept =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{lty =} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/glm-prediction-1} \end{center}

Both linear and logistic regressions provide an estimate for the conditional expectation:

\[
\mbox{E}(Y \mid X=x)
\]
which in the case of binary data is equivalent to the conditional probability:

\[
\mbox{Pr}(Y = 1 \mid X = x)
\]

\hypertarget{logistic-regression-with-more-than-one-predictor}{%
\subsection{Logistic regression with more than one predictor}\label{logistic-regression-with-more-than-one-predictor}}

In this section we apply logistic regression to the two or seven data introduced in Section \ref{two-or-seven}. In this case, we are interested in estimating a conditional probability that depends on two variables. The standard logistic regression model in this case will assume that

\[
g\{p(x_1, x_2)\}= g\{\mbox{Pr}(Y=1 \mid X_1=x_1 , X_2 = x_2)\} = 
\beta_0 + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2
\]
with \(g(p) = \log \frac{p}{1-p}\) the logistic function described in the previous section. To fit the model we use the following code:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fit_glm <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{glm}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data=}\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train, }\DataTypeTok{family =} \StringTok{"binomial"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{p_hat_glm <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit_glm, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type=}\StringTok{"response"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{y_hat_glm <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(p_hat_glm }\OperatorTok{>}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat_glm, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>     0.75}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Comparing to the results we obtained in Section \ref{two-or-seven}, we see that logistic regression performs similarly to regression.
This is not surprising, given that the estimate of \(\hat{p}(x_1, x_2)\) looks similar as well:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{# We use this function to plot the estimated conditional probabilities}
\NormalTok{plot_cond_prob <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat=}\OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{)\{}
\NormalTok{  tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p}
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.null}\NormalTok{(p_hat))\{}
\NormalTok{    tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\DataTypeTok{p=}\NormalTok{p_hat)}
\NormalTok{  \}}
\NormalTok{  tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{z=}\NormalTok{p, }\DataTypeTok{fill=}\NormalTok{p)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_raster}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{),}\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(fit_glm, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"response"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat =}\NormalTok{ p_hat) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{,  }\DataTypeTok{z=}\NormalTok{p_hat, }\DataTypeTok{fill=}\NormalTok{p_hat)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_raster}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{) }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/logistic-p-hat-1} \end{center}

Just like regression, the decision rule is a line, a fact that can be corroborated mathematically since

\[
g^{-1}(\hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 x_1 + \hat{\beta}_2 x_2) = 0.5 \implies
\hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 x_1 + \hat{\beta}_2 x_2 = g(0.5) = 0 \implies
x_2 = -\hat{\beta}_0/\hat{\beta}_2 -\hat{\beta}_1/\hat{\beta}_2 x_1
\]

Thus \(x_2\) is a linear function of \(x_1\). This implies that, just like regression, our logistic regression approach has no chance of capturing the non-linear nature of the true \(p(x_1,x_2)\). Once we move on to more complex examples, we will see that linear regression and generalized linear regression are limited and not flexible enough to be useful for most machine learning challenges. The new techniques we learn are essentially approaches to estimating the conditional probability in a way that is more flexible.

\hypertarget{exercises-51}{%
\section{Exercises}\label{exercises-51}}

1. Define the following dataset:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{make_data <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{n =} \DecValTok{1000}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{p =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }
                      \DataTypeTok{mu_0 =} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{mu_1 =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }
                      \DataTypeTok{sigma_0 =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{,  }\DataTypeTok{sigma_1 =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)\{}
\NormalTok{  y <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rbinom}\NormalTok{(n, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, p)}
\NormalTok{  f_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(n, mu_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, sigma_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  f_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{ <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{rnorm}\NormalTok{(n, mu_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, sigma_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  x <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, f_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, f_}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{  test_index <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{createDataPartition}\NormalTok{(y, }\DataTypeTok{times =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{p =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{list =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{)}
  \KeywordTok{list}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{train =} \KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ x, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{as.factor}\NormalTok{(y)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{         }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{test_index),}
       \DataTypeTok{test =} \KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =}\NormalTok{ x, }\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{as.factor}\NormalTok{(y)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{         }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(test_index))}
\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{dat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{make_data}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that we have defined a variable \texttt{x} that is predictive of a binary outcome \texttt{y}.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{dat}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ y)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{geom_density}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Compare the accuracy of linear regression and logistic regression.

2. Repeat the simulation from exercise 1 100 times and compare the average accuracy for each method and notice they give practically the same answer.

3. Generate 25 different datasets changing the difference between the two class: \texttt{delta\ \textless{}-\ seq(0,\ 3,\ len\ =\ 25)}. Plot accuracy versus \texttt{delta}.

\hypertarget{k-nearest-neighbors}{%
\section{k-nearest neighbors}\label{k-nearest-neighbors}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2008}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"mnist_27"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{# We use this function to plot the estimated conditional probabilities}
\NormalTok{plot_cond_prob <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat=}\OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{)\{}
\NormalTok{  tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p}
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.null}\NormalTok{(p_hat))\{}
\NormalTok{    tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\DataTypeTok{p=}\NormalTok{p_hat)}
\NormalTok{  \}}
\NormalTok{  tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{z=}\NormalTok{p, }\DataTypeTok{fill=}\NormalTok{p)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_raster}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{),}\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We introduced the kNN algorithm in Section \ref{knn-cv-intro} and demonstrated how we use cross validation to pick \(k\) in Section \ref{caret-cv}. Here we quickly review how we fit a kNN model using the \textbf{caret} package. In Section \ref{caret-cv} we introduced the following code to fit a kNN model:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_knn <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"knn"}\NormalTok{, }
                   \DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train,}
                   \DataTypeTok{tuneGrid =} \KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{k =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{71}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We saw that the parameter that maximized the estimated accuracy was:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_knn}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{bestTune}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This model improves the accuracy over regression and logistic regression:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_knn, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"raw"}\NormalTok{),}
\NormalTok{                mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>    0.835}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

A plot of the estimated conditional probability shows that the kNN estimate is flexible enough and does indeed capture the shape of the true conditional probability.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"True conditional probability"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_knn, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p, }\DataTypeTok{type =} \StringTok{"prob"}\NormalTok{)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"kNN"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p2, p1, }\DataTypeTok{nrow=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/best-knn-fit-1} \end{center}

\hypertarget{generative-models}{%
\section{Generative models}\label{generative-models}}

We have described how, when using squared loss, the conditional expectation/probabilities provide the best approach to developing a decision rule. In a binary case, the smallest true error we can achieve is determined by Bayes' rule, which is a decision rule based on the true conditional probability:

\[
p(\mathbf{x}) = \mbox{Pr}(Y=1 \mid \mathbf{X}=\mathbf{x}) 
\]

We have described several approaches to estimating \(p(\mathbf{x})\). In all these approaches, we estimate the conditional probability directly and do not consider the distribution of the predictors. In machine learning, these are referred to as \emph{discriminative} approaches.

However, Bayes' theorem tells us that knowing the distribution of the predictors \(\mathbf{X}\) may be useful. Methods that model the joint distribution of \(Y\) and \(\mathbf{X}\) are referred to as \emph{generative models} (we model how the entire data, \(\mathbf{X}\) and \(Y\), are generated). We start by describing the most general generative model, Naive Bayes, and then proceed to describe two specific cases, quadratic discriminant analysis (QDA) and linear discriminant analysis (LDA).

\hypertarget{naive-bayes}{%
\subsection{Naive Bayes}\label{naive-bayes}}

Recall that Bayes rule tells us that we can rewrite \(p(\mathbf{x})\) like this:

\[
p(\mathbf{x}) = \mbox{Pr}(Y=1|\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{x}) = \frac{f_{\mathbf{X}|Y=1}(\mathbf{x}) \mbox{Pr}(Y=1)}
{ f_{\mathbf{X}|Y=0}(\mathbf{x})\mbox{Pr}(Y=0)  + f_{\mathbf{X}|Y=1}(\mathbf{x})\mbox{Pr}(Y=1) }
\]

with \(f_{\mathbf{X}|Y=1}\) and \(f_{\mathbf{X}|Y=0}\) representing the distribution functions of the predictor \(\mathbf{X}\) for the two classes \(Y=1\) and \(Y=0\). The formula implies that if we can estimate these conditional distributions of the predictors, we can develop a powerful decision rule. However, this is a big \emph{if}. As we go forward, we will encounter examples in which \(\mathbf{X}\) has many dimensions and we do not have much information about the distribution. In these cases, Naive Bayes will be practically impossible to implement. However, there are instances in which we have a small number of predictors (not much more than 2) and many categories in which generative models can be quite powerful. We describe two specific examples and use our previously described case studies to illustrate them.

Let's start with a very simple and uninteresting, yet illustrative, case: the example related to predicting sex from height.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse)}
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(caret)}

\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(dslabs)}
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"heights"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{y <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{height}
\KeywordTok{set.seed}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1995}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{test_index <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{createDataPartition}\NormalTok{(y, }\DataTypeTok{times =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{p =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{list =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{train_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{test_index)}
\NormalTok{test_set <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{slice}\NormalTok{(test_index)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In this case, the Naive Bayes approach is particularly appropriate because we know that the normal distribution is a good approximation for the conditional distributions of height given sex for both classes \(Y=1\) (female) and \(Y=0\) (male). This implies that we can approximate the conditional distributions \(f_{X|Y=1}\) and \(f_{X|Y=0}\) by simply estimating averages and standard deviations from the data:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{params <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{train_set }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(sex) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{avg =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(height), }\DataTypeTok{sd =} \KeywordTok{sd}\NormalTok{(height))}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\NormalTok{params}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The prevalence, which we will denote with \(\pi = \mbox{Pr}(Y=1)\), can be estimated from the data with:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{pi <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{train_set }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{pi=}\KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(sex}\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{"Female"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{pull}\NormalTok{(pi)}
\NormalTok{pi}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.212}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Now we can use our estimates of average and standard deviation to get an actual rule:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{x <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{height}

\NormalTok{f0 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{dnorm}\NormalTok{(x, params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{avg[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{], params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sd[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{])}
\NormalTok{f1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{dnorm}\NormalTok{(x, params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{avg[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{], params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sd[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{])}

\NormalTok{p_hat_bayes <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{f1}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{pi }\OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{(f1}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{pi }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{f0}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{pi))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Our Naive Bayes estimate \(\hat{p}(x)\) looks a lot like our logistic regression estimate:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{heights }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{round}\NormalTok{(height)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(x) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{filter}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{n}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{>=}\StringTok{ }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{prob =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(sex }\OperatorTok{==}\StringTok{ "Female"}\NormalTok{)) }
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\NormalTok{naive_bayes_curve <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{data.frame}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{x =} \KeywordTok{seq}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{min}\NormalTok{(tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x), }\KeywordTok{max}\NormalTok{(tmp}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{x))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat =} \KeywordTok{dnorm}\NormalTok{(x, params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{avg[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{], params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sd[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{])}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{pi}\OperatorTok{/}
\StringTok{           }\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{dnorm}\NormalTok{(x, params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{avg[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{], params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sd[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{])}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{pi }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{              }\KeywordTok{dnorm}\NormalTok{(x, params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{avg[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{], params}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sd[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{])}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{-}\NormalTok{pi)))}
\NormalTok{tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, prob)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_line}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ naive_bayes_curve,}
             \DataTypeTok{mapping =} \KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x, p_hat), }\DataTypeTok{lty =} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/conditional-prob-glm-fit-2-1} \end{center}

In fact, we can show that the Naive Bayes approach is similar to the logistic regression prediction mathematically. However, we leave the demonstration to a more advanced text, such as the Elements of Statistical Learning\footnote{\url{https://web.stanford.edu/~hastie/Papers/ESLII.pdf}}. We can see that they are similar empirically by comparing the two resulting curves.

\hypertarget{controlling-prevalence}{%
\subsection{Controlling prevalence}\label{controlling-prevalence}}

One useful feature of the Naive Bayes approach is that it includes a parameter to account for differences in prevalence. Using our sample, we estimated \(f_{X|Y=1}\), \(f_{X|Y=0}\) and \(\pi\). If we use hats to denote the estimates, we can write \(\hat{p}(x)\) as:

\[
\hat{p}(x)= \frac{\hat{f}_{X|Y=1}(x) \hat{\pi}}
{ \hat{f}_{X|Y=0}(x)(1-\hat{\pi}) + \hat{f}_{X|Y=1}(x)\hat{\pi} }
\]

As we discussed earlier, our sample has a much lower prevalence, 0.21, than the general population. So if we use the rule \(\hat{p}(x)>0.5\) to predict females, our accuracy will be affected due to the low sensitivity:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat_bayes <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(p_hat_bayes }\OperatorTok{>}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Female"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Male"}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{sensitivity}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(y_hat_bayes), }\DataTypeTok{reference =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sex))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.213}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Again, this is because the algorithm gives more weight to specificity to account for the low prevalence:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{specificity}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{data =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(y_hat_bayes), }\DataTypeTok{reference =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sex))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.967}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This is due mainly to the fact that \(\hat{\pi}\) is substantially less than 0.5, so we tend to predict \texttt{Male} more often. It makes sense for a machine learning algorithm to do this in our sample because we do have a higher percentage of males. But if we were to extrapolate this to a general population, our overall accuracy would be affected by the low sensitivity.

The Naive Bayes approach gives us a direct way to correct this since we can simply force \(\hat{\pi}\) to be whatever value we want it to be. So to balance specificity and sensitivity, instead of changing the cutoff in the decision rule, we could simply change \(\hat{\pi}\) to 0.5 like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{p_hat_bayes_unbiased <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{f1 }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5} \OperatorTok{/}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{(f1 }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5} \OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{f0 }\OperatorTok{*}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{-}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{)) }
\NormalTok{y_hat_bayes_unbiased <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ifelse}\NormalTok{(p_hat_bayes_unbiased}\OperatorTok{>}\StringTok{ }\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Female"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Male"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note the difference in sensitivity with a better balance:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{sensitivity}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(y_hat_bayes_unbiased), }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sex))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.693}
\KeywordTok{specificity}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(y_hat_bayes_unbiased), }\KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(test_set}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{sex))}
\CommentTok{#> [1] 0.832}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The new rule also gives us a very intuitive cutoff between 66-67, which is about the middle of the female and male average heights:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{qplot}\NormalTok{(x, p_hat_bayes_unbiased, }\DataTypeTok{geom =} \StringTok{"line"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_hline}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{yintercept =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{lty =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_vline}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{xintercept =} \DecValTok{67}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{lty =} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/naive-with-good-prevalence-1} \end{center}

\hypertarget{quadratic-discriminant-analysis}{%
\subsection{Quadratic discriminant analysis}\label{quadratic-discriminant-analysis}}

Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA) is a version of Naive Bayes in which we assume that the distributions \(p_{\mathbf{X}|Y=1}(x)\) and \(p_{\mathbf{X}|Y=0}(\mathbf{x})\) are multivariate normal. The simple example we described in the previous section is actually QDA. Let's now look at a slightly more complicated case: the 2 or 7 example.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{data}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"mnist_27"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In this case, we have two predictors so we assume each one is bivariate normal. This implies that we need to estimate two averages, two standard deviations, and a correlation for each case \(Y=1\) and \(Y=0\). Once we have these, we can approximate the distributions \(f_{X_1,X_2|Y=1}\) and \(f_{X_1, X_2|Y=0}\). We can easily estimate parameters from the data:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{params <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{group_by}\NormalTok{(y) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{summarize}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{avg_1 =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{avg_2 =} \KeywordTok{mean}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{), }
            \DataTypeTok{sd_1=} \KeywordTok{sd}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{sd_2 =} \KeywordTok{sd}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{), }
            \DataTypeTok{r =} \KeywordTok{cor}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))}
\CommentTok{#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)}
\NormalTok{params}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Here we provide a visual way of showing the approach. We plot the data and use contour plots to give an idea of what the two estimated normal densities look like (we show the curve representing a region that includes 95\% of the points):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(y)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{fill =}\NormalTok{ y, }\DataTypeTok{color=}\NormalTok{y)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_ellipse}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{type=}\StringTok{"norm"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{lwd =} \FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/qda-explained-1} \end{center}

This defines the following estimate of \(f(x_1, x_2)\).

We can use the \texttt{train} function from the \textbf{caret} package to fit the model and obtain predictors:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(caret)}
\NormalTok{train_qda <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"qda"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We see that we obtain relatively good accuracy:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_qda, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>     0.82}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The estimated conditional probability looks relatively good, although it does not fit as well as the kernel smoothers:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{plot_cond_prob <-}\StringTok{ }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{p_hat=}\OtherTok{NULL}\NormalTok{)\{}
\NormalTok{  tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p}
  \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{!}\KeywordTok{is.null}\NormalTok{(p_hat))\{}
\NormalTok{    tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(tmp, }\DataTypeTok{p=}\NormalTok{p_hat)}
\NormalTok{  \}}
\NormalTok{  tmp }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{z=}\NormalTok{p, }\DataTypeTok{fill=}\NormalTok{p)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_raster}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{scale_fill_gradientn}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{colors=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"#F8766D"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"white"}\NormalTok{,}\StringTok{"#00BFC4"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_contour}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{breaks=}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{),}\DataTypeTok{color=}\StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(gridExtra)}
\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"True conditional probability"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_qda, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p, }\DataTypeTok{type=}\StringTok{"prob"}\NormalTok{)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"QDA"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p2, p1, }\DataTypeTok{nrow =} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/qda-estimate-1} \end{center}

One reason QDA does not work as well as the kernel methods is perhaps because the assumption of normality does not quite hold. Although for the 2s it seems reasonable, for the 7s it does seem to be off. Notice the slight curvature in the points for the 7s:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(y)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{fill =}\NormalTok{ y, }\DataTypeTok{color=}\NormalTok{y)) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_ellipse}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{type=}\StringTok{"norm"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{facet_wrap}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{~}\NormalTok{y)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/qda-does-not-fit-1} \end{center}

QDA can work well here, but it becomes harder to use as the number of predictors increases. Here we have 2 predictors and had to compute 4 means, 4 SDs, and 2 correlations. How many parameters would we have if instead of 2 predictors, we had 10?
The main problem comes from estimating correlations for 10 predictors. With 10, we have 45 correlations for each class. In general, the formula is \(K\times p(p-1)/2\), which gets big fast. Once the number of parameters approaches the size of our data, the method becomes impractical due to overfitting.

\hypertarget{linear-discriminant-analysis}{%
\subsection{Linear discriminant analysis}\label{linear-discriminant-analysis}}

A relatively simple solution to the problem of having too many parameters is to assume that the correlation structure is the same for all classes, which reduces the number of parameters we need to estimate.

In this case, we would compute just one pair of standard deviations and one correlation,
and the distributions looks like this:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{lapply}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{:}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\ControlFlowTok{function}\NormalTok{(i)\{}
  \KeywordTok{with}\NormalTok{(params[i,], MASS}\OperatorTok{::}\KeywordTok{mvrnorm}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1000}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{mu =} \KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(avg_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, avg_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{), }\DataTypeTok{Sigma =} \KeywordTok{matrix}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(sd_}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, sd_}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{sd_}\DecValTok{2}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{r, sd_}\DecValTok{1}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{sd_}\DecValTok{2}\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{r, sd_}\DecValTok{2}\OperatorTok{^}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{as.data.frame}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{setNames}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"x_1"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"x_2"}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{    }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{y  =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{c}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{,}\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{)[i]))}
\NormalTok{\})}
\NormalTok{tmp <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{do.call}\NormalTok{(rbind, tmp)}
\NormalTok{mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{y =} \KeywordTok{factor}\NormalTok{(y)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_point}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color=}\NormalTok{y), }\DataTypeTok{show.legend =} \OtherTok{FALSE}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{stat_ellipse}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(x_}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, x_}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =}\NormalTok{ y), }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ tmp, }\DataTypeTok{type=}\StringTok{"norm"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{lwd =} \FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.7\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/lda-explained-1} \end{center}

Now the size of the ellipses as well as the angle are the same. This is because they have the same standard deviations and correlations.

We can fit the LDA model using \textbf{caret}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_lda <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"lda"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}
\NormalTok{y_hat <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_lda, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test)}
\KeywordTok{confusionMatrix}\NormalTok{(y_hat, mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{test}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{y)}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{overall[}\StringTok{"Accuracy"}\NormalTok{]}
\CommentTok{#> Accuracy }
\CommentTok{#>     0.75}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When we force this assumption, we can show mathematically that the boundary is a line, just as with logistic regression. For this reason, we call the method \emph{linear} discriminant analysis (LDA). Similarly, for QDA, we can show that the boundary must be a quadratic function.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{train_lda <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{train}\NormalTok{(y }\OperatorTok{~}\StringTok{ }\NormalTok{., }\DataTypeTok{method =} \StringTok{"lda"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{data =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{train)}

\NormalTok{p1 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{() }\OperatorTok{+}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"True conditional probability"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{p2 <-}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{plot_cond_prob}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{predict}\NormalTok{(train_lda, }\DataTypeTok{newdata =}\NormalTok{ mnist_}\DecValTok{27}\OperatorTok{$}\NormalTok{true_p, }\DataTypeTok{type=}\StringTok{"prob"}\NormalTok{)[,}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggtitle}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"LDA"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{grid.arrange}\NormalTok{(p2, p1, }\DataTypeTok{nrow=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=1\linewidth]{book_files/figure-latex/lda-estimate-1} \end{center}
