Again note that we use relative paths exclusively.

In this file, we introduce an R command we have not seen: \texttt{save}. The \texttt{save} command in R saves objects into what is called an \emph{rda file}: \emph{rda} is short for R data. We recommend using the \texttt{.rda} suffix on files saving R objects. You will see that \texttt{.RData} is also used.

If you run this code above, the processed data object will be saved in a file in the \texttt{rda} directory. Although not the case here, this approach is often practical because generating the data object we use for final analyses and plots can be a complex and time-consuming process. So we run this process once and save the file. But we still want to be able to generate the entire analysis from the raw data.

Now we are ready to write the analysis file. Let's call it \texttt{analysis.R}. The content should be the following:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{library}\NormalTok{(tidyverse)}
\KeywordTok{load}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"rdas/murders.rda"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{murders }\OperatorTok{%>%}\StringTok{ }\KeywordTok{mutate}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{abb =} \KeywordTok{reorder}\NormalTok{(abb, rate)) }\OperatorTok{%>%}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{ggplot}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{aes}\NormalTok{(abb, rate)) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{geom_bar}\NormalTok{(}\DataTypeTok{width =} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{stat =} \StringTok{"identity"}\NormalTok{, }\DataTypeTok{color =} \StringTok{"black"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}
\StringTok{  }\KeywordTok{coord_flip}\NormalTok{()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If you run this analysis, you will see that it generates a plot.

\hypertarget{create-some-more-directories-using-unix}{%
\subsection{Create some more directories using Unix}\label{create-some-more-directories-using-unix}}

Now suppose we want to save the generated plot for use in a report or presentation. We can do this with the \textbf{ggplot} command \texttt{ggsave}. But where do we put the graph? We should be systematically organized so we will save plots to a directory called \texttt{figs}. Start by creating a directory by typing the following in the terminal:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\FunctionTok{mkdir}\NormalTok{ figs}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

and then you can add the line:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{ggsave}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"figs/barplot.png"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

to your R script. If you run the script now, a png file will be saved into the \texttt{figs} directory. If we wanted to copy that file to some other directory where we are developing a presentation, we can avoid using the mouse by using the \texttt{cp} command in our terminal.

\hypertarget{add-a-readme-file}{%
\subsection{Add a README file}\label{add-a-readme-file}}

You now have a self-contained analysis in one directory. One final recommendation is to create a \texttt{README.txt} file describing what each of these files does for the benefit of others reading your code, including your future self. This would not be a script but just some notes. One of the options provided when opening a new file in RStudio is a text file. You can save something like this into the text file:

\begin{verbatim}
We analyze US gun murder data collected by the FBI.

download-data.R - Downloads csv file to data directory

wrangle-data.R - Creates a derived dataset and saves as R object in rdas
directory

analysis.R - A plot is generated and saved in the figs directory.
\end{verbatim}

\hypertarget{initializing-a-git-directory}{%
\subsection{Initializing a Git directory}\label{initializing-a-git-directory}}

In Section \ref{init} we demonstrated how to initialize a Git directory and connect it to the upstream repository on GitHub, which we already created in that section.

We can do this in the Unix terminal:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\BuiltInTok{cd}\NormalTok{ ~/projects/murders}
\FunctionTok{git}\NormalTok{ init}
\FunctionTok{git}\NormalTok{ add README.txt}
\FunctionTok{git}\NormalTok{ commit -m }\StringTok{"First commit. Adding README.txt file just to get started"}
\FunctionTok{git}\NormalTok{ remote add origin }\KeywordTok{`}\ExtensionTok{https}\NormalTok{://github.com/rairizarry/murders.git}\KeywordTok{`}
\FunctionTok{git}\NormalTok{ push}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{add-commit-and-push-files-using-rstudio}{%
\subsection{Add, commit, and push files using RStudio}\label{add-commit-and-push-files-using-rstudio}}

We can continue adding and committing each file, but it might be easier to use RStudio. To do this, start the project by opening the Rproj file. The git icons should appear and you can add, commit and push using these.

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.3\linewidth]{productivity/img//windows-screenshots/VirtualBox_Windows-7-Enterprise_23_03_2018_14_53_32} \includegraphics[width=0.3\linewidth]{productivity/img//windows-screenshots/VirtualBox_Windows-7-Enterprise_23_03_2018_14_53_34} \includegraphics[width=0.3\linewidth]{productivity/img//windows-screenshots/VirtualBox_Windows-7-Enterprise_23_03_2018_14_53_35} \end{center}

We can now go to GitHub and confirm that our files are there.
You can see a version of this project, organized with Unix directories, on GitHub\footnote{\url{https://github.com/rairizarry/murders}}.
You can download a copy to your computer by using the \texttt{git\ clone} command on your terminal. This command will create a directory called \texttt{murders} in your working directory, so be careful where you call it from.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{git clone https}\OperatorTok{:}\ErrorTok{//}\NormalTok{github.com}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{rairizarry}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{murders.git}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
